Around 12 August 2020 (week of), an unidentified armed group attacked and killed a nurse in Beteva (Miandrivazo, Menabe).
On 13 August 2020, dahalo raided Sarodrano village (Maevatanana, Betsiboka) and stole 60 cows.
On 13 August 2020, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed the mayor of Miandrivazo (Miandrivazo, Menabe).
Around 14 August 2020 (as reported), dahalo and gendarmes clashed after dahalo attacked a shopkeeper in Ambalorao (Morombe, Atsimo Andrefana). 2 dahalo were subsequently arrested.
Around 14 August 2020 (as reported), dahalo attacked and injured a shopkeeper in Ambalaroa (Morombe, Atsimo Andrefana).
On 16 August 2020, 12 dahalo raided Mazavatakona village, Madiromirafy commune (Maevatanana, Betsiboka). They stole cattle and fled.
On 16 August 2020, an unidentified armed group abducted an albino girl from her home in Beravy (Toliary-II, Atsimo Andrefana).

On 16 August 2020, dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Beteva village (Miandrivazo, Menabe) following the assassination of the mayor on the 14th of August (coded separately). 10 dahalo were killed and 11 arrested. 2 gendarmes were seriously injured.

On 17 August 2020, an unidentified armed group shot and killed the village chief outside his home in Mahafasa, Andranomakoko commune (Farafangana, Atsimo Atsinanana). The attackers were subsequently arrested.

On 17 August 2020, locals demonstrated in Andranomakoko (Farafangana, Atsimo Atsinanana) demanding the release of the 3 suspects who shot and killed a chief earlier that day (coded separately). The police dispersed the demonstration and a curfew was imposed. [size=no report]
On 18 August 2020, dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Maintirano (Maintirano, Melaky). 2 dahalo and 4 gendarmes were killed. 2 boys who were taken hostage were rescued. 60 stolen cows were recovered.
On 18 August 2020, dahalo abducted 2 civilians in Maintirano district (Maintirano, Melaky) and stole 60 cattle.

On 20 August 2020, dahalo attacked and killed a civilian, abducting at least one other, while also stealing cattle in Bemokotra (Maevatanana, Betsiboka). The dahalo then killed 10 of the cows they stole. The hostage was later released unharmed.

On 20 August 2020, dahalo attacked and killed a trader while breaking into his shop in Sompirana village (Ambositra, Amoron I Mania). The dahalo beat the mother and daughter while stealing all the family's money and valuables.
Around 22 August 2020 (weekend of), dahalo abducted 2 civilians during a cattle raid in Morafenobe district (Morafenobe, Melaky).

Around 23 August 2020 (weekend of), dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Miandrivazo district (Miandrivazo, Menabe) after dahalo abducted 2 hostages during a cattle raid the day before (coded separately). The 2 hostages were rescued and the stolen cattle returned. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column16: Madagascar Tribune; AFP; L'Express de Madagascar
column17: On 23 August 2020, prisoners and police clashed at Farafangana prison (Farafangana, Atsimo Atsinanana) when the prisoners attempted a mutiny. Prisoners attacked guards with rocks and stole a gun as they escaped. Police then fired on fleeing prisoners. 88 prisoners escaped, and between 20 and 23 prisoners were killed. 45 escaped prisoners were re-captured, 18 are still on the run. Some reports suggested that coronavirus restrictions on prisoners prompted the escape. [size=at least 88]
On 23 August 2020, dahalo attacked and killed a farmer while stealing money from his family in Andohanikifika village, Ankadinondry Sakay commune (Tsiroanomandidy, Bongolava).

On 25 August 2020, locals demonstrated in front of the police station in Mahabo commune (Mahabo, Menabe) in reaction to police shooting a suspected criminal earlier in the day whom the population believed to be innocent. Police and gendarmes intervened to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]
On 25 August 2020, dahalo raided more than 100 zebus from civilians in Betroka district (Betroka, Anosy).
On 25 August 2020, in response to a dahalo raid earlier in the day, fokonolona clashed with dahalo, recovering their cows and arresting 2 dahalo in Betroka district (Betroka, Anosy).

Around 26 August 2020 (week of), gendarmes clashed with dahalo near Mahazoarivo (Isandra, Haute Matsiatra) during an attempted cattle raid. 6 dahalo were killed in the clash, including the leader called Zafikely.
Around 29 August 2020 (between 28 - 30 August), gendarmes clashed with dahalo in Ankadirano (Maevatanana, Betsiboka). 1 dahalo was killed in the clash and 11 zebus were released.

Around 29 August 2020 (between 28 - 30 August), military forces clashed with dahalo near Sakafia within Marotsiraka commune (Amboasary-Atsimo, Anosy). This followed an abduction in the nearby town of Sakafia. An abducted child and some stolen zebu were released, but no fatalities and/or injuries reported.
Around 29 August 2020 (between 28 - 30 August), dahalo abducted a child and stole cattle from civilians in Sakafia within Marotsiraka commune (Amboasary-Atsimo, Anosy).

Around 29 August 2020 (between 28 - 30 August), dahalo attacked and killed 2 civilians in Ambohi-mana-rivo, commune of Manakara (Manakara Atsimo, Vatovavy Fitovinany). Dahalo stole money and goods from civilians.
On 29 August 2020, dahalo attacked, injured and stole goods from street traders on their way to Besalampy (Besalampy, Melaky).
Around 31 August 2020, police and dahalo clashed in Mokotra-maro (Besalampy, Melaky). 2 dahalo were arrested after the clash. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 1 September 2020, a group of locals, including a local fokonolona leader, lynched and killed 3 suspected murderers previously arrested by gendarmerie in Sahasinaka (Manakara Atsimo, Vatovavy Fitovinany). [size=no report]
On 2 September 2020, dahalo clashed with gendarmerie 40km from Ambohimatazana in Andriamena commune (Tsaratanana, Betsiboka). 2 were injured in the clash and zebu were recovered.
On 2 September 2020, dahalo stole 50 cows from pastoralists in Marosakoana (Tsaratanana, Betsiboka). No fatalities and/or injuries reported during the raid.
On 2 September 2020, dahalo attacked and killed a civilian in Bemandavo (Morafenobe, Melaky). Dahalo also stole 60 zebus.
On 2 September 2020, dahalo clashed with gendarmerie and a fokonolona militia in Mafaibony (Morafenobe, Melaky). Some dahalo were injured and zebus were recovered. No fatalities reported.
On 2 September 2020, police clashed with a dahalo who resisted their arrest in Ambalakindresy (Ambohimahasoa, Haute Matsiatra). 1 dahalo, allegedly a witch doctor, was killed in the clash.
On 5 September 2020, dahalo looted valuables from civilians in Mahazoma (Maevatanana, Betsiboka).
On 6 September 2020, dahalo militia clashed with fokonolona militia members near Tsinjomay (Tsiroanomandidy, Bongolava) after dahalo stole cattle. Fokonolona recovered 13 zebus.
On 6 September 2020, dahalo militia stole 70 zebus from Tsinjomay (Tsiroanomandidy, Bongolava). Fokonolona later recovered 13 of them (coded separately).
On 6 September 2020, about 40 dahalo attacked and killed 4 civilians in Beombilahy (Mandoto, Vakinankaratra). 7 other civilians were injured.

On 7 September 2020, demonstrators burned tires and barricaded the roads as they demonstrated in Imerimanjaka (Antananarivo Atsimondrano, Analamanga). They were demonstrating against the lack of food in the area. Police dispersed the demonstrators. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, dahalo clashed with and severely injured a gendarme in Manandaza, located on the outskirts of Malaimbandy (Mahabo, Menabe). Some reports say 3 fatalities.

On 8 September 2020, dahalo clashed with gendarmes in Maevatanana district (Maevatanana, Betsiboka). Gendarmerie had pursued dahalo ""a long way"" after an attack on civilians in a nearby location. 1 gendarme was killed.
On 8 September 2020, dahalo attacked and killed 2 civilians in Maevatanana district (Maevatanana, Betsiboka).

On 9 September 2020, a mob attacked 2 gendarmes as they attempted to arrest a mentally-unwell civilian in Tsarahonenana (Antsirabe II, Vakinankaratra). The gendarmes fired shots to warn them to cease, killing 1 civilian and injuring another. The mob then captured one gendarme, only to later release him. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, gendarmerie clashed with and killed a known dahalo militia leader in Ambalabe village, Tsiroanomandidy (Tsiroanomandidy, Bongolava). He had been known for looting villages in surrounding areas.

On 10 September 2020, dahalo clashed with gendarmerie and fokonolona communal militia members in Meba, near Tomboarivo (Aboasary, Anosy). 3 dahalo were killed. A hostage was rescued and stolen cattle recovered. 1 fokonolona was injured.
On 10 September 2020, dahalo abducted a boy in Tomboarivo (Amboasary, Anosy). They also stole zebus.

Around 11 September 2020 (between 10 - 12 September), dahalo attacked a truck on the road between Ambiky and Ambatomainty, leading to Tulear (Toliara II, Vakinankaratra). The dahalo stole money. A few civilians were wounded.
On 14 September 2020, a local mob and fokonolona killed 2 suspected criminals in Port-Berge (Port-Berge, Sofia). [size=no report]
On 15 September 2020, dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Mangamila (Anjozorobe, Analamanga). 1 dahalo leader was killed.
Around 16 September 2020 (week of), locals demonstrated against the dismissal of a mayor in Bekitro (Bekily, Androy). [size=no report]

On 18 September 2020, street traders, mostly women, protested against a sanitation decision by the Urban Municipality of Antananarivo in Antananarivo (Antananarivo Renivohitra, Analamanga). [size=no report]
On 19 September 2020, dahalo attacked and killed 2 civilians while stealing cows in Betioky-Sud district (Betioky Atsimo, Atsimo Andrefana). 95 cows were taken.

On 19 September 2020, dahalo clashed with fokonolona and gendarmerie in Sakaraha district (Sakaraha, Atsimo Andrefana). The clash followed a dahalo raid on a village where they stole 95 cows (coded separately). 4 people were injured.

On 19 September 2020, street vendors demonstrated by burning tires and blocking traffic in Ambohimangakely (Antananarivo Avaradrano, Analamanga) until police used tear gas to disperse them. They were demonstrating because of a new law restricting them from selling their goods along the road. [size=no report]

Around 19 September 2020 (between 18 - 20 September), dahalo clashed with gendarmes in Ikalamavony (Ikalamavony, Haute Matsiatra). 2 dahalo were killed. The gendarmes came upon the dahalo with stolen cattle and were alerted to their presence due to a shoot out that happened between dahalo members.
Around 19 September 2020 (between 18 - 20 September), dahalo clashed with gendarmes in Bemokotra (Maevatanana, Betsiboka). 1 dahalo leader was captured and stolen cows were recovered.
On 20 September 2020, street vendors demonstrated against the closing of ""illegal"" markets in Behoririka (Antananarivo Renivohitra, Analamanga). [size=no report]
On 20 September 2020, dahalo attacked and killed a civilian in Ambatofolo, near Soahany (Antsalova, Melaky). The dahalo demanded money before executing the civilian
On 20 September 2020, dahalo attacked civilians and stole cattle in Ambolomborona (Ambatofinandrahana, Amoron I Mania). 1 civilian was injured and 15 cattle stolen.

On 24 September 2020, dahalo clashed with military forces in Ambalakindresy commune (Ambohimahasoa, Haute Matsiatra). Several dahalo surrendered after the clash and weapons were seized. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 24 September 2020, dahalo clashed with military forces in Fiadanana commune (Ambohimahasoa, Haute Matsiatra). Several dahalo surrendered after the clash and weapons were seized. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

Around 24 September 2020 (as reported), dahalo and military forces clashed in Ankiria (Befotaka, Atsimo Atsinanana). 2 dahalo were arrested after the clashes during an attempted cattle raid. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.
On 25 September 2020, a dahalo clashed with gendarmerie in Soahany (Antsalova, Melaky). 1 dahalo was killed and a civilian staying with the dahalo.

On 25 September 2020, a group from Tsararano gathered axes, knives and sticks and attacked residents in Fiofio, Mahajanga district (Mahajanga I, Boeny). The group, including fokonolona, were attempting to avenge an attack carried out by residents of Fiofio who attacked a young man earlier when passing through Fiofio. The Fiofio youth responded to the attack with stone throwing. Police and gendarmerie intervened and dispersed the group by firing into the air, arresting 2. 2 people were injured. [size=no report]
On 25 September 2020, dahalo and gendarmerie clashed in Besaraha village, Antsalova district (Antsalova, Melaky). 2 dahalo were killed.
On 29 September 2020, several moto taxi drivers demonstrated near Analakinapa (Maintirano, Melaky) against criminal attacks on moto taxi drivers. [size=several]

On 30 September 2020, a group of locals attempted to lynch a suspected rapist in Marovazaha (Anjozorobe, Analamanga). Gendarmes intervened to prevent the lynching but the man was injured. [size=no report]

On 4 October 2020, a group of locals beat up and injured an alleged thief in the Ambohitsoa area of Antananarivo (Antananarivo Renivohitra, Analamanga). Police intervened and took the alleged thief to the hospital. [size=no report]

On 5 October 2020, dahalo clashed with gendarmerie in Andafiha, Mahasoa commune (Mahabo, Menabe). 3 hostages were released which were captured earlier this day in a nearby location. 1 dahalo was wounded in the clash.
On 5 October 2020, dahalo abducted a woman and stole goods in Anandrobe (Ambatondrazaka, Alaotra Mangoro).
On 5 October 2020, dahalo abducted a woman and her 2 daughters along with zebu in Ambinanisoa, Mahasoa commune (Mahabo, Menabe).

On 5 October 2020, dahalo clashed with gendarmerie and fokonolona near Anandrobe (Ambatondrazaka, Alaotra Mangoro). Dahalo had abducted a woman and stolen goods in nearby Anandrobe the same day before being chased down by security forces. The abducted woman was rescued by security forces. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.
On 9 October 2020, 30 dahalo attacked and killed 2 pastoralists and stole 30 cattle in Ambondro (Belo Sur Tsiribihina, Menabe).

On 9 October 2020, dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Ankilimiangy (Mahabo, Menabe). The clash happened as the dahalo were attempting a cattle raid on the village. Two dahalo were captured alive. No injuries and/or fatalities reported.

On 12 October 2020, street traders protested by carrying banners and disrupting traffic in Antananarivo (Antananarivo Renivohitra, Analamanga). The protesters were angry because the city restricted the areas where they were selling goods. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Tsiafajavona Ankaratra (Vakinankaratra, Ambatolampy). Four hostages were taken by the dahalo and subsequently released after the clash. One dahalo leader was captured alive and another dahalo was arrested later. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.
On 22 October 2020, dahalo and gendarmes clashed in Antsirasira, a town in the commune of Saratravoaka (Bongolava, Tsiroanomandidy). 1 gendarme was killed.
On 22 October 2020, dahalo looted cattle from civilians in Vohitsoa village (Bongolava, Tsiroanomandidy).
On 22 October 2020, a group of locals attacked and killed a captured dahalo prisoner in Vohitsoa (Bongolava, Tsiroanomandidy). [size=no report]

Police block protest over fuel shortage
Students riot over book allowances
Police teargas peaceful protest of students
Police stop planned peaceful demonstration
Police beat students
Police clash with rioting students
Police beat students
Police clash with rioting students
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Rioters clash with police. 19 people die in the riots overall
Police harass and chase journalist away from covering presidents visit
Home and office of opposition candidates petrol-bombed
House of opposition leader firebombed
Student and political activist found dead, likely murdered
Police fire tear gas at illegal street vendors, who in turn throw stones at police and destroy surrounding property. 18 arrested.
A group attacks a group of women and strips their clothes off because the women were wearing trousers, which is not the norm.
2,000 women stage a ""sit-in"" protest for their right to wear trousers following harassment by a group.
A journalist was arrested for publishing a story where he referred to the President of Malawi as a ""tin pot dictator. ""

Security Measures: Riot police patrol the streets of two cities when ""illegal"" police declare they will hold an anti-Mutharika conference. The police warned they would use forces to break up and protests.

A leading Malawi rights group called Thursday on President Bingu wa Mutharika to resign or face ""civil disobedience"" for mismanaging the economy and trampling on democratic freedoms. The group gives the President a 60-day ultimatum.

Ralph Kasambara, former attorney general of Malawi and outspoken critic of President Bingu wa Mutharika, has his office broken into and fire bombed by a group of men. He and his supporters subdue the men and call to police. When the police arrive, however, it is Kasambara who is arrested, charged with kidnapping.
Anti-Mutharika rioters torch a police station.
Police forces arrested an opposition lawmaker who is the son of ex-president Bakili Muluzi, after his supporters torched a police station over the weekend.
Workers of a labor organization stage a sit-in for a salary increase and the dismissal of the CEO.
Police fire tear gas at students protesting against a fees hike.
Police in Malawi's capital Lilongwe fired teargas to disperse angry street vendors who were reportedly protesting the arrest of their colleague. The protesters responded by throwing stones at police.

Hundreds gather in the streets to protest the administration of President Joyce Banda and its economic policies. Witnesses and analysts thought the numbers were underwhelming, considering previous protests against the president.
Members of a civil servants trade union gathered at Capital Hill and blocked roads in protest of their compensation.

Police in Blantyre used tear gas to disperse school pupils marching against a public workers strike. Though most of the demonstrators were peaceful, there were a small minority of students who threw rocks at police. The ages of the students were between 6 and 15 years of age. The police said they were forced to fire tear gas at the school pupils protest because it had been ""hijacked by hooligans.""
Police disperse a group of protesting students without reported incident. The students were calling for an end of a two week long public workers strike, which included teachers.

Following the arrest of former senior Malawian government officials, including Cabinet ministers, a group of 500 took the streets of Lilongwe and set up road barricades in protest of President Joyce Banda and her administrations efforts to silence opposition. Several vehicles were smashed and policemen assaulted during the protests.

Arrests: Malawian police arrested a number of former and current government officials in relation to an alleged transition plot against Joyce Banda that followed the death of former President Bingu wa Mutharika in April 2012. Among those arrested are Peter Mutharika, a former foreign minister and brother of the late president, as well as current minister of economic planning Goodall Gondwe.

Non-violent activity: Former First Lady Callista Mutharika of the DPP holds a press conference following the arrest of her brother-in-law and other political supporters for a perceived coup attempt against President Joyce Banda in April 2012. Police fired tear gas to disperse the DPP supporters gathered at the conference.

Following the arrest of former senior Malawian government officials, including Cabinet ministers, supporters of the DPP took to the streets of Blantyre to protest current President Joyce Banda. Police dispersed the crowd with tear gas.

Police fire canisters of teargas to disperse opposition protesters near the Songani Trading Centre. Though the event was described as ""hell braking loose"", the protesters did not respond with violence and there were no injuries reported.
Members of the Civil Servants Trade Union (CSTU) blocked roads in the Capital Hill area in protest for an increased monthly wage. The event was peaceful and without incident.

Students of the University of Malawi (Unima) in the eastern city of Zomba on Friday marched to the District Commissioner's offices to voice their anger against a hike in tuition fees for self-sponsored students of the college.

Police attack a photojournalist outside the National Assemble building in Lilongwe. The journalist was attacked as she was taking pictures of Consumer Association of Malawi Executive Director, John Kapito, after he presented a petition to the Speaker of Parliament.
Mob kills man suspected of child abuse
Residents riot and burn home of man suspected of mutilating dead bodies
Mob of villagers kills suspected cattle thief
Budget director for the Minsitry of Finance was shot before releasing a report on corruption.
Students protested against a new education policy.
Students rioted against the District Education Manager over teacher transfers. Police intervened.
Seven houses were burnt down by members of the Alimitambo after an individual was taken into police custody for allegedly killing a resident of Alimitambo.
Students vandalised the school to protest recent burglaries.
Students protested school conditions. Police were called in but did not intervene.
Students from two schools rioted due to their teachers not teaching and other schools having access to teachers.
Students set a teachers house on fire after a school assembly warning about sexual relationships between males and females. Police arrested several people.
Two people were burned to death as a result of mob justice.

Students rioted the school after a teacher banned students from class for not paying for a broken chair. When police arrived, students pelted stones at the police to which the police responded with tear gas.
A man attempted to enter the home of his ex wife but when the ex heard someone enter the house, she called for the community. The community rioted/acted as mob justice and killed the man.
Protests for ""President Joyce Banda to resign and announced a series of protests and disobedience campaigns. ""
Protests for ""call for the disclosure of the names of 68 public officials and business people being tried for corruption in the country""

Opposition DPP supporters rioted Bandas speech In Thyolo. They threw stones at PP supporters and broke several cars. Police intervened by firing teargas and rubber bullets. 1 rioter and 1 police officer died in the chaos.
After the riots, members of the Peoples Party beat up an aid to the oppositions presidential candidate.
A petrol bomb was thrown into a DPP car.

Police condemned mob justice at Mawila elementary school where ""where students allegedly assaulted to death a man and set him ablaze for allegedly stealing two pairs of trousers and a pair of shoes from one of the hostels early morning Tuesday. ""
Key witness for cashgate scandal murdered
In Mangochi, Muslims protested for a stop to the use of Muslim women as dancers in political rallies. Banda was using women dressed in the hijab and performing the ""Zikiri"" at political rallies.
An aspiring councillor donated goods to women vendors at Blantyres market, leading to a riot over the donations, involving minor injuries to at least two women and one child
Reported that supporters of Hophmally Makande perpetrated violence to disrupt opponents rally last week at Cape Maclear; two injured as a result
Shooting of a charcoal seller in southern district Mulanje by a guard of an official of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party Leston Mulli as reported by Nyasa Times

Irate citizens vandalized school blocks, ransacked some shops and set ablaze ballot boxes and papers in the most populous slum residential area of Ndirande, in protest over late arrival of voting materials to the area

In Blantyre city centre angry youths staged an impromptu mini-protest chanting anti-government slogans; police fired tear-gas at least once to disperse crowd; also disgruntled voters torched a house set to be used as a voting station at Chiwembe Township in commercial city of Blantyre
Protesters blocked a road with tree branches, forcing the president to use an alternative route from the presidential palace to the polling station in the eastern town of Zomba
Protests broke out in Lilongwe after President Banda declared elections void and called for a repeat election

Rriots broke out in Limbe, a sprawling township east of Blantyre, over Bandas declaration; stone- throwing mobs were seen smashing cars and blocking roads; crowds of mainly young people in the township set flaming tyres in the streets and threw stones at police who tried to charge the mobs from their vehicles

column7: UDF: United Democratic Front; PP: Peoples Party; Students (Malawi)
column17: Police, using teargas and rubber bullets, clashed with rioters demanding a recount of Malawis disputed presidential elections; a teenager was killed by an exploding tear gas cannister which he tried to throw back at riot police; six students were also injured, as were three police officers and another civilian
A man was set ablaze by an angry mob who mistook him for a thief. He died from his injuries.
Interns from the Kamuzu College of Nursing (KCN) held a demonstration at the healthy facility today to demand payment of allowances and better accommodations.

Police set fires and used teargas to remove 86 boys from traditional initiation camps where they were being held for longer than the typical month long ritual. Some locals threw rocks at the police, but no one was injured.
A man allegedly chopped off his wifes hand following a quarrel, and a community mob beat him in response.
As teachers boycotted classes at two primary schools in the Bvunguti Zone, students rioted and disturbed lessons at other schools. The students broked glass and some sustained injuries
Teachers at two schools in the Bvunguti Zone boycotted against allowance policies.

Muslim militia attacked Muslims for encroaching on land belonging to Blantyre Islamic Mission. No deaths reported. Police arrested some Muslims thought to be Boko Haram, although Muslim groups in Malawi say the Muslim Militia is not connected to Boko Haram.
500 schoolchildren broke classroom windows and damaged cars to protest a strike by their teachers in Blantyre. Police fired tear gas. Reports of arrests, no injuries.
Police shoot and kill an off-duty Malawi Defence Force soldier Price Lameck in Zomba.
Women from the Nkhotakota Health Centre maternity wing marched to protest over increased deaths of infants due to inadequate medical facilities.
Youth wearing DPP T-shirts beat up a bicycle taxi operator in Mzuzu for allegedly insulting DPP President Mutharika.
Members of the Democratic Progressive Party beat up supporters of the Peoples Party at a rally in Chitipa. Rioters wielded pangas and threw stones. Police arrested 3.

Lecturers of the University of Malawi Chancellor College in Zomba stage a sit in to support to the university workers strike. Support staff of the University of Malawi Chancellor College in LIlongwe and Zomba also went on strike demanding 45% pay raise a few days before.

Community members of Habibu Village Traditional Authority in Machinga attacked and injured 2 policemen. After discovering a deceased 8-year old girls body, community members wanted to carry out mob justice, and assaulted police as they took four suspects in for questioning.

Vigilante militia destroyed 10 houses belonging to the Kawowa family in Nkhata Bay following slow police response to the murder of Anthony Kamanga by a member of the Kawowa family. Three elderly men arrested.

After a house was robbed in Lilongwe, neighbours (which included deputy commander of Malawi Defence Forces Griffin Supuni) beat a private security guard in front of the robbed house. After police arrived, Supuni allegedly assaulted one of the policmeman. Supuni was arrested.

An unidentified group dressed in military attire and armed with panga knives threw a petrol bomb at the Area 23 Police Unit in Lilongwe, and kidnapped and attacked an officer. Sergeant Trouble Muotcha was later found in a maize field with severe cuts to the head. He was taken to Kamuzu Central Hopsital where he died.

Malawi civil societies staged protests calling for electoral reform, including a law that would require the elected president to receive more than 50% of votes cast. Demonstrations also called for financial reforms, following reports that the National Aids Commission disbursed over US$120,000 to First Lady Gertrude Mutharikas Beauty Malawi Trust and cultural group Mulhako wa alhomwe for non-HIV/AIDS activities. Similar demonstrations were held in Lilongwe, Mzuzu and Karonga. Protesters gave the government a 100-day deadline for response.

Malawi civil societies staged protests calling for electoral reform, including a law that would require the elected president to receive more than 50% of votes cast. Demonstrations also called for financial reforms, following reports that the National Aids Commission disbursed over US$120,000 to First Lady Gertrude Mutharikas Beauty Malawi Trust and cultural group Mulhako wa alhomwe for non-HIV/AIDS activities. Similar demonstrations were held in Lilongwe, Blantyre, and Karonga. Protesters gave the government a 100-day deadline for response.

Malawi civil societies staged protests calling for electoral reform, including a law that would require the elected president to receive more than 50% of votes cast. Demonstrations also called for financial reforms, following reports that the National Aids Commission disbursed over US$120,000 to First Lady Gertrude Mutharikas Beauty Malawi Trust and cultural group Mulhako wa alhomwe for non-HIV/AIDS activities. Similar demonstrations were held in Lilongwe, Mzuzu and Blantyre. Protesters gave the government a 100-day deadline for response.

Malawi civil societies staged protests calling for electoral reform, including a law that would require the elected president to receive more than 50% of votes cast. Demonstrations also called for financial reforms, following reports that the National Aids Commission disbursed over US$120,000 to First Lady Gertrude Mutharikas Beauty Malawi Trust and cultural group Mulhako wa alhomwe for non-HIV/AIDS activities. Similar demonstrations were held in Blantyre, Mzuzu and Karonga. Protesters gave the government a 100-day deadline for response.

A mob killed a man alleged to have trespassed into Kazirila sugarcane field in Nkhotakota district to steal tires from an irrigation pivot. When approached by 3 cane guards, the man reportedly wielded a panga knife. A vigilante militia then found for the man and assaulted him to death.
Government secondary school teachers hold sit-ins to demand pay.

9 people including 2 police officers injured were during riots in Monkey Bay. Rioters from Sumbi village had entered the District Council hall to protest against traditional leaders agreeing to give land to the government to build a hotel. 6 arrested.
Vendors stoned police after police destroyed illegally erected shops in Lilongwe. Police used tear gas to disperse the rioters.
Government secondary schools teachers march on Parliament demanding pay, two weeks after hosting sit-ins.
Secondary school students vandalized the Robert Laws secondary school in Mzimba, in protest of the suspension of their fellow students the prior week. 17 arrested.
Employees of Lilongwe City Council held a sit-in to demand a raise in salary.
Students at Kamuzu College of Nursing in Lilongwe protested against unpaid salaires and failure to implement a salary hike.
Democratic Progressive Party loyalists protested over the weekend in Mangochi, demanding the resignation of the minister of local government and rural development Trasizio Gowelo.

Taxi and minibus operators and vendors marched in Mchinji, demanding the removal of the police officer inspector for incompetence and harassment towards motorists. Some rioters pelted stones at passersby and at council offices.
Vendors hold a demonstration at the Regional Trade Offices in Blantyre to protest against foreign entrepeneurs selling used tyres in the market.
Protests against the xenophobic attacks against Malawian citizens in South Africa.
Protests and boycotts against South African shops and outlets in Limbe following violence against Malawians in South Africa.
Protests and boycotts against South African shops and outlets in Lilongwe, following violence against Malawians in South Africa.
Protests and boycotts against South African shops and outlets in Blantyre, following violence against Malawians in South Africa.
Church members of Nkhoma congregation ransacked church property in Livingstonia in protest of the proposed transfer of their pastor.
Protests in Nkhotakota demanding transfer of council officials.
Police officer raped a 12-year old girl at Bangula flood victims camp in Nsanje.
Angry mob beat to death a man caught stealing maize in Thyolo. The man had attacked the maize owner with a panga knife.
Civil society organisations protested the government sale of Malawi Savings Bank.
Angry mob killed a robber in Lilongwe.
Divided factions of the Malawi Congress party physically clashed in Lilongwe, over new appointments that pastor leader Lazarus Chakwera made to the executive of the party.
Angry mob beat and burnt a man to death in Ndirande after he was caught stealing.
Protests in Mzuzu advocating for a federal system of government.
Protests against taxes on SMS and internet.
Anti-Corruption Bureau director of corporate services Issa Njauju abducted and shot dead in Lilongwe. His body was found two days later behind government buildings.
Residents torch Chilomoni Police Station in protest of a man being allegedly killed by police.
Rioters destroyed property they claim was illegally taken in Chinyamamanyama village in Salima District. When police deployed to the area, one officer shot and hospitalised.
Police beat a woman on suspicion that she was involved in torching Chilomoni police station the prior month.
University students rioted, closed part of Masauko Chipembere Highway in Blantyre, demanding pay allowances. Police fired tear gas.
Crowds gathered at the courthouse in Karonga and pelted stones at police that were planning to release people suspected of abducting albino children. Police fired tear gas.
Students protest in Dedza against the transfer of teachers.
Vigilante militia kills a man suspected of using magic to sleep with women.
Rioters broke windows, demanding the resignation of council members.
42 district council staff arrested for protesting at the district council office, demanding Rosemary Moyo leave office.
Protests over health services.
Mob kill a suspected witch in Karonga.
Mob beat and burned to death a couple in Kasimba thought responsible for witchcraft and crocodile attacks.
Protests against the starvation of patients in Malawis public hospitals.
Bus drivers block roads and set tires on fire protesting against high cost of impoundinng vehicles.
Rioters damaged police station property after release of suspected thief.
Angry mob burnt to death an alleged theft in Soza village, Mulanje district.
Mob beat up a suspected witch in Malenga Sanga.
Rioters injured a policeman while recovering bags of fertilizer meant for farms. Police used tear gas to disperse crowds.
DPP treasurer shot and injured in Nzirawaingwe near Mzuzu.
Vigilante militia kill a women accused of robbery in Mulange.
Rioters destroyed church property and set fire to vehicles after hearing a rumour that a pastor had turned into a snake. Police fired tear gas.
Kasungu residents riot and block roads protesting against sale of maize.
Mtakataka residents riot and block roads protesting against sale of maize.
Mob killed 4 in Chimbalanga who they suspected of using witchcraft to kill a young woman - the woman was killed by lightning strike.
Kasungu residents riot and block roads for second day protesting against sale of maize.
Mtakataka residents riot and block roads for second day protesting against sale of maize.
Vendors protest in Dzenza over placement of stalls.
Mob rioted and burnt a courthouse in Machinjiri. 2 policemen injured.

column9: Government of Malawi (2014-); DPP: Democratic Progressive Party
column17: Rioter stoned and destroyed billboard showing President Mutharikas face. Police later arrested him.
Vigilante militia lynch to death 4 people in Mwanza who were found in possession of bones belonging to albinos.
Angry mob killed a man caught stealing tobacco in Chamkoma.
Protesters in Mzuzu address the government about food shortage and economic crisis.
MCP members protest demand release of a legal advisor accused of coup plotting. Police fired tear gas.
Vigilante militia burn to death 7 suspected of witchcraft because they were found with bones.

column9: AFORD: Alliance for Democracy; PP: Peoples Party; MCP: Malawi Congress Party
column17: Unknown group weilding pangas injured civilians gathered a joint MCP-PP-Aford rally, 4 injured.
Angry mob killed a suspected murderer in Dedza.
Angry mob killed two criminals in Chinyonga near Blantyre.
Disabled people protest the banning of street beggars.
Vigilante militia kill a suspected murderer in Chikwawa.
Villagers protest corruption of local chief.
Villagers in Salima erected barricades to block district commissioners office, protesting the continued rule of Chief Kuluwunda.
Rioters ransacked market and protested food shortages after a market official accidentally shot his gun during patrol and killed a person.
Neno district staff protest non-payment of salaries, blocked gates to offices.
A man who stabbed his in-law during a dispute over land is burnt to death by community members.
A number of properties are destroyed and people injured during a clash between three families over ownership of local land. A former MP of the area is implicated in funding the violence.
Armed group with machetes entered a church in Lilongwe and attacked civilians. Several injured and taken to hospital. Group reportedly targeting the pastor who was not present that day in church.
Muslim chief, who had converted to Islam, attacked and seriously injured by unknown group.
Police in Nchalo fired teargas to disperse crowd rioting over the distribution of maize. 2 people including an officer sustained serious injuries.
Police in Nsanje fired teargas to disperse crowd rioting over the distribution of maize.
DPP member led half-naked demonstrations against abductions and killings of albinos.
Students at Chancellor College rioted against a proposed fee hike. The police responded with teargas, causing running battles between police and students.

Students at Chancellor College burnt tyres on the road, preventing visiting US Second Lady, Jill Bidens progress to Machinga. Police later arrested 11 students and the principal has shut down the university.
Police arrested 14 students after violent protests against fee hikes at the Malawi Polytechnic in Blantyre.
Parents of students arrested during fee hike protests at the Malawi Polytechnic were chased away from a vigil that they were holding at the Blantyre Police Station.
A group of villagers disrupted the Area Development Committee meeting and beat up the secretary, who is also son to a suspended chief.
Students at the Kamuzu College of Nursing in Lilongwe blocked the entrance to the hospital to protest the fee increases. The police attacked the students, firing teargas and confining them to campus.
Although police had previously denied Billy Mayaya authorisation to protest against the Customary Land Bill, the police allowed the protests to go ahead peacefully.
Students at Kamuzu College of Nursing Blantyre held a peaceful protest against fee hikes
Students at Kamuzu College of Nursing Lilongwe held a peaceful protest and delivered a letter petitioning for lower fees to the District Commissioner

A group of angry villagers burned down the house of the newly appointed Group Village Head Woman in Kaluunda. They also burned down 20 other houses belonging to relatives and supporters of the new Head Woman, and killed livestock.
Civil Society Organisations staged a protest in solidarity with the students protesting the increase in fees.
Civil Society Organisations staged a protest in solidarity with the students protesting the increase in fees.
Civil Society Organisations staged a protest in solidarity with the students protesting the increase in fees.
Civil Society Organisations staged a protest in solidarity with the students protesting the increase in fees.
Non-violent activity: Malawi Congress Party members involved in an internal party squabble were apprehended in an attempt to petrol bomb the party headquarters in Lilongwe.
MCP members assaulted the lawyer who delivered the court summons for the MCP President
The Teachers Union of Malawi has been holding a sit-in to force the government to meet their demands
Primary School students marched to the Lilongwe District Education Office to protest the teachers strike. Police fired teargas to disperse them
Residents in Karonga have held a wave of demonstrations protesting the corruption of local officials.
Residents in Mchinji have held a wave of demonstrations protesting the corruption of local officials.

Students of the Lilongwe University of Agriculture and Natural Resources protested the increase in fees by blocking roads with burning tires. The police fired teargas at the students and at a new crew. 26 studetns were arrested
Violence erupted at a rally addressed by the Mulanje Governor. The police rushed to the rally and quelled the violence, arresting villagers.
Police intercepted a march against the persistant black-outs in Malawi. The leader, Mayaya, and 2 others were arrested.
MUST students demonstrated against persistent water shortages. The government has now closed the university indefinitely.
Community members stormed the police station because they believed that the police had detained a person believed dead. The rioters were dispelled with teargas.
Students protested to force the government to reopen Mzuzu University
1000 people participated in a protest organised by the Catholic and Evangelical churches against abortion and homosexuality
2000 people participated in a protest organised by the Catholic and Evangelical churches against abortion and homosexuality

Residents of Lilongwes squatter township, Mtsiridza, attacked the house of a family accused of satanism. The family was not at home. When the police came to intervene, the crowd turned on the police and set their vehicle alight.
A mob attacked and burned a man who they suspected of killing a security guard.
Villagers in Mulanje ganged up against the soldiers after one of them shot a local farmer. They managed to isolate and beat one of the soldiers.
A soldier beat and then shot a farmer cultivating his crops close to Mulanje Mountain as part of a military crack-down on farming and charcoal-burning in Mulanje
Over 600 ex-miners are protesting at the officers of the District Commissioner in Karonga over their pension
Local maize traders are holding a sit-in at the grain procurement offices to protest the fact that they have not been paid by the parastatal
Students at Soche Technical College protested the lack of electricity at the school. They blockaded the roads around the school.
Students at Soche Technical College protested the lack of electricity at the school. They blockaded the roads around the school.
3 men attempted to rob a church. They were apprehended by a mob, who beat one of the men to death.

Local minibus drivers struck to protest a ruling to prevent them from collecting passengers in undesignated areas. When the police came, the drivers threw stones at them, so the police retaliated by firing teargas.
Malawian civil society organisations held a day of protest government impunity. The turnout was low, but they delivered the petition to parliament successfully.

A junior police officer in Ntcheu district was rescued from an angry mob that wanted to kill him for stealing. When the community members noticed that amongst the thieves there was a police officer, they got angry and started beating the thieves.
An angry mob in Lilongwe burned to death a conman for impersonating a Malawi Revenue Authority (MRA) officer.

Angry students from Mawila Private Secondary School and villagers near the school in Liwonde have damaged a businessman's house after suspecting the owner of kidnapping a female student from the school. Police later managed to arrest eight students and some villagers.
Students in Dowa district earlier blocked the M1 road and stoned cars at Mponela in protest after a car hit to death one of the students.
A man who was suspected of stealing cattle was summoned to the police station. He ran away, but was caught by a mob of fellow villagers and killed.
MCP supporters gathered at the airport to welcome the party president, Chakwera, but the rally was broken up by the Riot Police.
An angry mob of villagers killed an unknown man who was caught stealing goats in Chisikwa village
People who had not been paid for road maintenance projects run by the Malawi Social Action Fund gathered at the Rumphi Rural District Council offices for a sit-in to demand their pay.
A 34-year-old robbery suspect in the central district of Ntcheu was killed by an angry mob.
A fight broke out between supporters of the DPP and MCP attending the funeral of Chief Lukwa's mother. Some vehicles were smashed and senior government officials had to be rushed to safety.
Chancellor College studetns held a peaceful demonstration in Zomba, asking the president to intervene in the dispute that is keeping the university closed.

Residents of Madede in Mzimba District burnt to death a 34-year-old man identified as Biko Mhlanga for allegedly breaking into a house of a businessperson where he is alleged to have stolen K600, 000.

column9: MCTU: Malawi Congress of Trade Unions
column17: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) cadets and supporters interrupted Labour Day activities in Blantyre as they clashed with some workers whom are Malawi Congress of Trade Unions (MCTU) members.
22 Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) cadets beat up Malawi police officers in Ntcheu in clashes.
An angry mob in a village in Lilongwe has beaten to death a man who wanted to steal goats in the village.
Residents from Chileka in Blantyre burnt a man suspected to be a thief.
Karonga residents through Karonga-Chitipa Cultural Heritage marched to Parliament Building in the capital Lilongwe to present a petition that condemned government's plans to relocate a refugee camp.
During protests, police in Blantyre shot teargas at primary school pupils who had barricaded the M1 road and sang anti-government chants in protest against a nationwide teachers' strike.
Riots by pupils took place in Balaka district. Police are reported to have used tear gas on students.
Riots by pupils took place in Ntcheu district. Police are reported to have used tear gas on students.
Officer in charge for Chileka Police was rushed to Mlambe hospital in Blantyre after protesting pupils beat him up.
Minibus operators in Blantyre and Mzuzu also took to the streets against new rules imposed against them.
Minibus operators in Blantyre and Mzuzu also took to the streets against new rules imposed against them.
A man accused of witchcraft was killed by villagers in the district of Karonga.
Minibus operators in Liliongwe protested despite an agreement of Lilongwe Minibus Owners Association and Minibus Owners Association of Malawi (MOAM) to call off the protests.
A mob in Limbe has killed a man who masqueraded as a prostitute to rob people.

column7: Police Forces of Malawi (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: Prison warders took to the streets of Lilongwe blocking roads and chanting protest songs to force the government to pay heed to their concerns. No violence was reported.
A mob in Lilongwe killed a woman after community members accused her of killing a 10-year-old boy through witchcraft.

People around Dyeratu area in Malawi's Shire Valley district of Chikhwawa have destroyed property belonging to Prophet Shepherd Bushiri's Enlightened Christian Gathering (ECG) church's home cell leader.
Angry residents at Area 49 in Lilongwe fatally assaulted a suspected robber.
In a mob attack, in Nsanje the local community has killed a suspected criminal by beating and burning him.
Police in Lilongwe arrested a woman who was a part of the protests against gender based violence.
Some illegal vendors torched Mzuzu City Council (MCC) Planning Offices at Mzuzu Stadium.
Community members in Nsanje killed a village headman after accusing him of working with ""blood suckers"".
Two Malawi Congress Party members were arrested after they led on marching in Nsanje singing campaign songs for the party.
In Kande in Nkhata Bay District, an angry mob ransacked Senior Chief Fukamapiri's office where some items were also stolen.
Police in Limbe have arrested 21 people suspected of burning a South African pastor's car after accusing him of being a blood sucker.
In Nsanje, during a political rally, some Democratic Progressive (DPP) youth cadets assaulted Gaka Community Radio reporter.

In Bangula, Malawi Congress Party gathered and staged a protest. They deflating the tyres near a police check point, there was a heavy presence of the police officer who arrived to guard the vehicles as irate mob wanted to torch it.
In Blantyre a 22-year-old man, was torched and another was stoned to death following suspicion of sucking people's blood, Malawi Police confirmed.
A mob at Nkhoma in Lilongwe has killed a man for torturing his houseboy to death.
Villagers from the area of Senior Group Village Headman Kamwendo maliciously damaged property at the school.
A man was caught stealing a goat and was beaten to death when he attempted to run away in the area of Mzuzu.
Mob justice occurred at Chakuma Village in the area of Senior Chief Chikumbu in Mulanje.
An angry mob around Kabwazi trading centre in Dedza broke into a police unit, dragged a suspected robber out of the unit and killed him.
Fourteen Rastafarians have been arrested in Mchinji for protesting the arrest of fellow Rastafarians who were found cultivating cannabis sativa.
An angry mob destroyed property belonging to a child abduction suspect in Dowa district
On 1 April, an angry mob in Lilongwe murdered a man after he went on rampage injuring 10 people in display of behaviour which was suspected to have been influenced by Cannabis sativa.
On 5 April, police in Mchinji have instituted investigations over the death of an armed robber who was murdered by an angry mob.

Before the elections of 10 April, members of the MCP political party were injured in politial violence in Mulanje in an attack by members of the Democratic Progressive Party. One person went to hospital.
On 18 April, a mob killed a man believed to have molested a woman in Lilongwe.

On 23 April, students from a School in Kasungu protested and stormed the district's municipal offices in protest against the council's decision to sell a football ground that belong to the school. They threw stones on property in protest.
On 26 April, the ruling DPP party held a protest in Blantyre in support of the President.
On 27 April, civil society organised uncommon anti-government protests in Lilongwe, Karonga, Mruru and Zomba. Members of the MCP joined the protest.
On 27 April, civil society organised uncommon anti-government protests in Lilongwe, Karonga, Mruru and Zomba. Members of the MCP joined the protest.
On 27 April, civil society organised uncommon anti-government protests in Lilongwe, Karonga, Mruru and Zomba. Members of the MCP joined the protest.
On 27 April, civil society organised uncommon anti-government protests in Lilongwe, Karonga, Mruru and Zomba. Members of the MCP joined the protest.

On 2 May, angry villagers clashed with police in Zalewa as they wanted the police to release to them a man suspected of killing a bicycle taxi operator so that they should administer mob justice. They damaged the police station and blocked the road that passes through Zalewa.
On 8 May, police in Karonga district rescued a man when a mob wanted to kill him on witchcraft suspicion.

On 9 May, residents at Bolero in Rumphi damaged shops and property owned by foreign nationals after a Rwandan shop owner strangled his watchman to death. Police rushed to the scene to control the riots and during their operation nine police officers sustained various injuries.
On 9 May, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supporters in Mulanje South marched to show their dissatisfaction with their Member of Parliament Bon Kalindo.
On 30 May, an angry mob in the commercial city of Blantyre has demolished eight houses belonging to murder suspects.

On 1 June, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supporters protested in Mulanje against legislator Patricia Kaliati for supporting Vice President Saulos Chilima as the party's candidate in next year's elections.
On 15 June, a green march took place in Blantyre over awareness of plastic.

On 29 June, an angry mob on stoned to death unidentified man at Ntanje Village in Chimwala area in Mangochi while another escaped when the two were spotted pushing a motor bike suspected to have been stolen.

On 12 July, a Burundian man was assaulted to death and later his body set on fire in Ntcheu by angry mob who suspected him and other business persons of buying human body parts for cultism to acquire wealth in the area.
On 15 July, angry community members in Chitipa set on fire a councillor's vehicle after the politician hit a cyclist dead.
On 1 August, residents from Chiradzulu have demolished three houses after guards at Chikale Estate killed a man over cutting trees.
On 19 August, two United Transformation Movement (UTM) vehicles were damaged in Mangochi in what appears to be a case of political sabotage.
On 6 September, two police officers have been injured as they were controlling an irate mob targeting a Burundian trader whom they accused of organising young men to have same sex.

On 21 September. Several hundred anti-graft activists took to the streets of ""Malawi's biggest cities"" (coded as Lilongwe, Blantyre and Mzuzu) to protest against alleged corruption in the government of President Peter Mutharika.

On 21 September. Several hundred anti-graft activists took to the streets of ""Malawi's biggest cities"" (coded as Lilongwe, Blantyre and Mzuzu) to protest against alleged corruption in the government of President Peter Mutharika.

On 21 September. Several hundred anti-graft activists took to the streets of ""Malawi's biggest cities"" (coded as Lilongwe, Blantyre and Mzuzu) to protest against alleged corruption in the government of President Peter Mutharika.
On 25 September, students went on rampage at Mziza Mission Secondary School, damaging, burning and stealing school property.
On 3 October, at least seven Americans resident in Malawi held a peaceful protest as the convoy of the US First Lady Melania Trump passed by at Area 30 in the capital city Lilongwe.
On 7 October, an angry mob at Mbayani in Blantyre beat to death a 33-year-old man for hacking his ex-lover in an attempt to kill her.

On 17 October, police in Salima arrested eight bicycle taxi operators who were part of a group that protested on the premises of the district council against the council collecting annual license fees.
On 25 October, people at Ekwendeni Trading Centre beat to death a farm owner in what appears to be a mob attack following the killing of his tenant.

On 11 November, at least 10 UTM party supporters were injured, one seriously, after they were ambushed at Mlambe Trading Centre in Salima. Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) members are reported to have emerged from a nearby bush and attacked the unsuspecting supporters.
On 14 November, Malawi Police in Thyolo swiftly rescued a murder suspect from the jaws of mob justice, as the mob was moving towards him to kill after setting his house ablaze.

On 14 November, Malawi Police in Zomba fired teargas to disperse Zomba Police Secondary School students, who were demonstrating against management's decision to expel about 150 students who were not selected to the institution. The students blocked the road between Police College main entrance and the boys' hostel where they were stoning vehicles.
On 15 November, a man was killed in a mob attack after he was allegedly found slaughtering two goats in Lilongwe.
On 20 November, an angry mob at Kalamwa village, Traditional Authority Mabuka in Mulanje district, stoned to death a 55 year old man on allegation that he was a wizard.

On 21 November, a group of rastafarians staged protests at the Civic Office in the commercial capital Blantyre. They want Rasta children to be allowed to attend classes without removing their dreadlocks.
On 22 November, a man was killed in a mob attack after being caught on allegations of theft of a motorcycle in Mitundu area of Lilongwe.
On 25 November, a man was killed by an angry mob in Likuni area of Lilongwe due to his habitual committing of crimes.

On 23 December, police in Zomba clashed with members of the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) after the police tried to stop the party's rally saying President Peter Mutharika was expected to pass through a road near the venue.
On 24 December, in Salima, a suspected cattle thief has been burnt to death after he was caught by a mob.
On 31 December, mobs armed with pangas stabbed a man to death at his home in Nkhata bay on New Year's Eve because he was an albino.
On 9 January, the Indian community in Lilongew Malawi has protested against a bail application by a man suspected of murdering his wife.
18 January. Residents invaded Nsanje Police Station demanding the release of a murder suspect to lynch him.
18 January (on or around). DPP militias beat a lawmaker and the UTM National Director of Youth in Mulanje.
20 January. Suspected Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supporters assaulted UTM party members who were on their way to a meeting in Mangochi.
29 January. Demonstrators, led by NGO Gender Coordination Network, have protested peacefully in Lilongwe to oppose increasing cases of political violence against UTM members and supporters.
06 February (on or around). Hundreds of Malawian women, including members from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), held a peaceful march to denounce political violence against women in Lilongwe.

20 February. Suspected AFORD disrupted a UDF rally in Rumphi. The riot was targeted at AFORD member, Frank Mwenifumbo, who is currently running with the UDF president. The rioters demanded a AFORD cloth back from Mwenifumbo, stating that he can no longer be part of AFORD. The rioters entered the rally with pangas. Size of demonstration unknown.

20 February. Women, including female political party members, marched in the Mangochi District, against political violence during campaign meetings. Members from the Gender Coordination and the 50-50 Campaign Management Agency also joined the march. [size=no report]
21 February. Four cadets from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) beat and seriously injured a supporter from the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) in Nsanje. They also burnt an MCP flag.

On 21 February 2019, a man suspected of having abducted a person with albinism was tortured and killed by the police while in custody in the police station in Lilongwe (Central). 12 police officers were later arrested, including the Commissioner.
21 February. Kabaza operators marched in the Dedza district to protest a rise in the montly tax they need to pay for their operation. [size=no report]

22 February. Students protested at the Soche Technical College, Blantyre, demanding the reintroduction of the Trade Test Examining Board, to release the 2017 results, and the introduction of four year degrees. The police have been called in to disperse the protest. [size=no report]
06 March. A mob from Mchinji attacked a man who are suspected of sexually assaulting his step daughter. Police intervene, the man was taken to a hospital. [size=no report].

column7: APAM: Association of People with Albinism
column17: 06 March. A group of 200 people living with albinism, joined by 500 sympathisers, marched to the parliament building, Lilongwe, in protest against the killing and abduction of people living with albinism. Police forces attempted to stop protesters to move towards the parliament building for a while. [size=700].

12 March. Beneficiaries of the 2018/19 Public Works Programme, that included Rumphi Residents Association (RRA), in Rumphi protested outside the District Commissioner's office, demanding the payment of their wages for work done between December 2018 and January 2019. [size=no report].
05 April. Ntchisi vendors marched to the office of the district council, demanding that issues of service delivery and the Ng'oma trading center be addressed. [size=no report].
09 April. Community members from Blantyre killed a former Malawi Defence Force soldier for attempting to rape a woman in the community. [size=no report].

20 April (on or around). Malawi President Peter Mutharikais convoy and two Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vehicles were smashed in Lilongwe. Five suspects from the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) have been arrested. [size=5].

column9: EUEOM: European Union Election Observation Mission
column17: 12 May. Two election observers from the European Union Election Observation Mission (EU EOM) have been attacked in lower Shire district, almost 45 km from Malawi's commercial capital, Blantyre. [size=no report].

15 May. Two Malawi Congress Party (MCP) have been attacked by Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Youth Cadets with sticks and stones in Kachere along the main road to Nsanje after the welcome party for the vice-president of the MCP. [size=no report].
22 May (on or around). A mob has beaten a man suspected of wanting to hijack a motorcycle in Kasungu. [size=no report].
25 May. An angry mob stoned a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) office, burned DPP flags and blocked the M1 road with burning tyres in Mponela Dowa. [size=no report].
26 May. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) blocked roads with burned tyres in Lilongwe. The demonstration was in response to the poll of the recent elections. [size=no report].
26 May. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) blocked roads with burned tyres in Mchinji. The demonstration was in response to the poll of the recent elections. [size=no report].

26 May. Demonstrators marched in Chikwawa central over the election results. Demonstrators believe that the winning candidate from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) manipulated the poll results to win the elections. [size=no report].

28 May. Police have sprayed tear gas at the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) headquarters in Lilongwe. The police said that the headquarters are used for violent demonstrators. MCP members said that no demonstration took place in or near the building. [size=no report].

28 May. Members of the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) demonstrated at the Chimwaza Trading Centre, Dowa. The demonstrators said that their party leader was robbed of the presidency by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Police have arrested 15 demonstrators for political violence. [size=no report].

29 May. Demonstration action have been reported in Chikwawa. Teachers demonstrated, demanding allowances for work they have done for work done during the election. Police used teargas to disperse the demonstrators after demonstrators blocked roads with stones and branches. [size=no report].
31 May. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters marched in the streets of Lilongwe, in demonstration against the recent election results. [size=no report].

04 June. Demonstration action have been reported in Blantyre. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters walked from the party's reginal offices to the Blantyre central business district in demonstration against the recent election results, claiming the election results a fraud. [size=no report].

04 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters marched through Lilongwe in demonstration against the recent election results, claiming the election results a fraud. The demonstrators stormed into the ministerial and civil servant officers while holding tree branches. [size=no report].

06 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters demonstrated in Nkhotakota in response to the recent election results. The police fired teargas canisters at the demonstrators. Two demonstrators suffered injuries. [size=no report].

06 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters demonstrated at the party's headquarters in Lilongwe in response to the recent election results. The police fired teargas canisters at the demonstrators. Two demonstrators suffered injuries. [size=no report].

column7: MCP: Malawi Congress Party; PP: Peoples Party; FP: Freedom Party
column17: 07 June. Hundreds of Malawi Congress Party (MCP), People's Party (PP) and Freedom Party (FP) supporters marched through the streets of Mzuzu, in demonstration over the irregularities in the 21 May presidential elections. The demonstration was initially delayed by police and authorities from Mzuzu City Council (MCC) who blocked the demonstrators. [size=100].
07 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters marched through the streets of Karonga, in demonstration over the irregularities in the 21 May presidential elections. [size=no report].
11 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) from Kasungu vandalized President Mutharika's Billboard during a demonstration. The police used teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].

column7: MCP: Malawi Congress Party; PP: Peoples Party
column17: 11 June. Supporters of the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) and People's Party (PP) marched from Chinamwali Trading Centre, along the M3 Road, via Chirunga and Kalimbuka roads, on their way to MCP Eastern Region offices in Zomba. The demonstration over the irregularities in the 21 May presidential elections. [size=no report].

13 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) supporters shoved the Secretary General of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Grelzedar Jeffrey wa Jeffrey, outside the Lilongwe High Court during a conference on the Constitutional Court. [size=no report].

column7: MCP: Malawi Congress Party; PP: Peoples Party
column17: 13 June. Malawi Congress Party (MCP) and People's Party (PP) supporters marched in Ntcheu in demonstration over the irregularities in the 21 May presidential elections. [size=no report].

19 June. President Peter Mutharika's security detail had to make changes to his route after police fired teargas at Malawi Congress Party (MCP) demonstrators who barricaded the M1 main road in Lilongwe with burning tires. The demonstrators threw rocks at the police. The demonstration was against the May elections. Demonstrators claim that there were irregularities during the elections. [size=no report].

column7: HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition; UTM: United Transformation Movement; MCP: Malawi Congress Party
column17: 20 June. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) Malawi Congress Party (MCP), and Malawi's United Transformation Movement (UTM), demonstrated in Mzuzu. The demonstrators are demanding the Malawi Electoral Commission chairperson to resign due to the suspected irregularities during the 21 May elections. [size=1000].

column7: HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition; UTM: United Transformation Movement; MCP: Malawi Congress Party
column17: 20 June. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), Malawi Congress Party (MCP), and Malawi's United Transformation Movement (UTM), burned shirts and flags from the Democratic Progressive Party during a demonstration in Lilongwe. The demonstrators are demanding the Malawi Electoral Commission chairperson to resign due to the suspected irregularities during the 21 May elections. Police said that shops were also looted during the demonstration and two police officers have been injured when demonstrators threw rocks at the police. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=1000].

column7: HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition; UTM: United Transformation Movement; MCP: Malawi Congress Party
column17: 20 June. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) Malawi Congress Party (MCP), and Malawi's United Transformation Movement (UTM), demonstrated in Blantyre. The demonstrators are demanding the Malawi Electoral Commission chairperson to resign due to the suspected irregularities during the 21 May elections. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=1000].

column7: HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition; UTM: United Transformation Movement; MCP: Malawi Congress Party
column17: 20 June. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) Malawi Congress Party (MCP), and Malawi's United Transformation Movement (UTM), demonstrated in Zomba. The demonstrators are demanding the Malawi Electoral Commission chairperson to resign due to the suspected irregularities during the 21 May elections. [size=1000].

01 July. Traditional Authority Chimwala in Mangochi residents marched to the District Commissioner's offices, demanding to receive their compensation for damages to their property during the rehabilitation of the Liwonde-Mangochi Road. [size=60].

04 July. Demonstrators vandalized billboards of the current president during a demonstration in Zomba. Demonstrators also barricaded roads with burning tires. Police fired teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].

04 July. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), gathered in Lilongwe to demonstrate against the re-election of the current president, who they claim came into office due to fraud. A group of youth, part of the demonstration, allegedly looted a supermarket and an electronics shop during the demonstration. Demonstrators burned tires and damaged statues at the Parliament Building. [size=3500].

04 July. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), who are demonstrating against the election results of the 21 May elections, were attacked by twenty-five Progressive Democratic Party (DPP) Youth Cadets, armed with knives, sticks, and machetes, in Blantyre. [size=no report].

04 July. Demonstrators, demonstrating against the 21 May election results, allegedly vandalized the offices of the Electricity Supply Corporation of Malawi (Escom), commercial banks in Mzuzu, looted and destroyed public structures, including Mzuzu Prison Building and Karonga District Commissioner (DC)'s office. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].
05 July. Demonstrators marched through the streets of Lilongwe. The demonstration is in response to the 21 May election results which is marred with allegations of fraud. [size=3000].
05 July. Demonstrators marched through the streets of Blantyre. The demonstration is in response to the 21 May election results which is marred with allegations of fraud. [size=3000].

10 July. Women, associated with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) marched in Blantyre to show support for the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson Justice Jane Ansah, who is under pressure to resign. [size=1000].

15 July. Dozens of students for the Lilongwe University of Agriculture and Natural Resources (Luanar) Bunda Campus demonstrated in front of the campus over increased university fees. The demonstrators barricaded entrance of the Mitundu Trading Centre with stones and burned tires and threw stones at passing vehicles. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds. The police also arrested 14 students. [size=dozens].

19 July. Demonstrators, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), marched through the streets of Lilongwe, demanding the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson, Jane Ansah, to resign. [size=no report].
19 July. The Human Rights Defender Coalition (HRDC) held a peaceful demonstration in Blantyre. The demonstrators are demanding that the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) to resign. [size=no report].
21 July. A mob have killed a suspected burglar after he was found in a house in Chiradzulu. [size=no report].
21 July. The Southern Region Office of the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) in Blantyre was petrol bombed by Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supporters. [size=no report].

23 July. Judiciary workers demonstrated at the High Court in Blantyre over terms of conditions of their contracts and called for the resignation of the Chief Justice Andrew Nyirenda and Registrar Agnes Patemba. Police and the demonstrators have reportedly been involved in an altercation. Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].

25 July. Demonstrators burned bushes in front of the official residence of President Peter Mutharika in Lilongwe. The demonstrators planned to submit a petition calling for the resignation of the Chairperson of the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) due over irregularities the presidential election in May. The demonstrators were blocked by the Malawi Defence Force and the police. [size=1000].

25 July. Thousands of demonstrators marched from Mnjili Community Day Secondary School to M'mbelwa District Council offices in Mzimba where they presented a petition calling for the resignation of Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson Jane Ansah for allegedly mishandling the May 21 Tripartite Elections. The police fired tear gas at the demonstrators. Demonstrators threw bricks and wood at the police, broke shop windows, and blocked roads with burning tires. [size=1000].

26 July. The Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) marched from the Lilongwe Community Ground through Mchesi to city center to hand over a petition that demands the dismissal of the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson. The demonstrators, who intended to march to Kamuzu Palace, were blocked by Malawi defense Force (MDF) soldiers and police. [size=no report].

06 August. Demonstrators clashed with police in Lilongwe after demonstrators damaged property at a bank and attempted to break in. The demonstration was arranged by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) organised in order to demand the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson Jane Ansah to resign. Demonstrators set an armored vehicle alight during the demonstration. Police fired teargas at demonstrators to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].
06 August. Demonstrators barricaded roads with burning tires in Blantyre. The demonstration was to call for the resignation of the country's electoral body. [size=no report].
07 August. Demonstrators held a vigil in Lilongwe. No further information available. [size=no report].
09 August. The offices of the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) vice president, Sidik Mia, in Blantyre have been fire-bombed by suspected DPP militants.

column7: Reunion Timber Millers Union; Labour Group (Malawi)
column17: 22 August. Protests led by Reunion Timber Millers Union, has been reported at the Vipsya Plantations, also known as Chikangawa Forest, in Mzimba. The demonstrators are demanding equal investment opportunities. [size=no report].

22 August. Unknown group have thrown petrol bombs at the house of a Human rights activist in Lilongwe. The activist is part of Malawi's Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) that leads protests around Malawi, demanding the resignation of Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) chairperson Jane Ansah.

12 September. Demonstrators in Rumphi damaged a Hewe Police Unit and threw stones at police officers, injuring one. The demonstration was in response to the arrest of three people who have been accused of witchcraft. [size=no report].

18 September. Demonstration action, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), has been reported in Blantyre. The demonstration was in response to the 21 May elections. Demonstrators are demanding the resignation of the Malawi Electoral Commission head. [size=1000].

18 September. Demonstration action, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), has been reported in Lilongwe. The demonstration was in response to the 21 May elections. Demonstrators are demanding the resignation of the Malawi Electoral Commission head. Demonstrators barricaded the M1 between Lilongwe and Mzuzu with stones and branches. [size=1000].

19 September. Demonstration action, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), has been reported in Mzuzu. The demonstration was in response to the 21 May elections. Demonstrators are demanding the resignation of the Malawi Electoral Commission head. Demonstrators barricaded the M1 between Lilongwe and Mzuzu with stones and branches. Demonstrators threw stones at the police. The military disperse the crowds. [size=1000].

19 September. Demonstration action have been reported in Karonga. Demonstrators attacked the Malawi Defence Force (MDF) soldiers, injuring one soldier. The soldiers used whips to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].

column9: HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition; UTM: United Transformation Movement; MCP: Malawi Congress Party
column17: 25 September. Cadres of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) demonstrated at the Kamuzu Highway in Blantyre. The DDP blocked Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC) demonstrators from demonstrating. Demonstrators pelted each other with stones. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds, mainly the HRDC demonstrators who included UTM and MCP leaders. DPP demonstrators have reportedly injured some demonstrators and have been taken to hospital. Police have reportedly used teargas inside a hospital where demonstrators sought refuge. [size=no report].
26 September. Demonstration action has been reported in Mzuzu. The demonstration was against the quota system in public secondary schools. Police presence has been reported. [size=no report].
26 September. Police fired teargas at vioent demonstrators in Kasungu. Taxi drivers were demonstrating over the reintroduction of bicycle taxi fees. [size=no report].
26 September. Police fired teargas at demonstrators in Rumphi. Demonstrators were marching against the quota systems in secondary schools. Shops were pelted with stones. [size=no report].

01 October. Demonstration action, led by the Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), have been reported in Lilongwe. The demonstrators are calling for the resignation of the current chairperson of the Malawi Electoral Commission, Jane Ansah, accused of vote rigging. The demonstrators were escorted by the Malawi Defence Force. Clashes between the demonstrators and the police have been reported earlier. Police fired teargas to disperse the crowds. Stone pelting at the police have also been reported. Police have arrested 20 people for public violence. [size=1000].
