02 October. Demonstration action, planned by Human Rights Defenders Coalition (HRDC), have been reported in Lilongwe. He demonstration turned violent. Demonstrators pelted stones at Malawi Defence Force (MDF) soldiers after they intervened in the demonstration. Three trucks have been set alight. [size=no report].
03 October. A mob stabbed a man to death in Chikwawa after the deceased strangled his wife to death and then ran outside his house to inform a friend, where he was met by the mob.

08 October. A police officer has been killed with a stone during a demonstration in Lilongwe. Demonstrators blocked DDP supporters from travelling to Lilongwe where the current president where to speak at a rally. Demonstrators threw rocks at police. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report].

08 October. Street vendors demonstrated in Limbe against the Blantyre City Council (BCC) who aimed to relocate the vendors to the flea market. Streets were barricaded roads with burning tyres. Shops were looted. Police arrived at [the scene. [size=no report].

On 8 October 2019, 13 women, a child, and 3 teenagers were sexually assaulted by 17 police officers in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) during an operation following the death of a police officer and protests against the President on the same day. In August 2020, the High Court has ordered the police to compensate the victims.
08 October. Pupil from the Blantyre Secondary School demonstrated in the city, accusing their school administration of corruption. [size=no report].
08 October. Students from the Machinga Teachers Training College demonstrated in Machinga over water issues at the college. [size=no report].

10 October (on or around). The car of the Human Rights Defenders Coalition chairperson Timothy Mtambo was shot at six times by unknown armed men while he was driving between Mtandire and Bingu Stadium along Kaunda Road in Lilongwe.

14 October 2019. Students from Soche Technical College and Technical, Entrepreneurial and Vocational Education (TEVET) marched to the TEVET offices, Lilongwe, demanding better services. [size=no report].

15 October 2019. Six people have been killed in a mob-related attack in Nkhata Bay. Residents from Mkondezi went to Msakanene accusing residents of theft and raided a house. Residents from Msakanene retaliated as assaulted the residents from Mkondezi. 21 houses have been set alight. Three people have been arrested.

16 October 2019. Students from the Thyolo Secondary School damaged school property, including burning an administration block. The demonstration was over alleged mismanagement at the school. [size=no report].
18 October 2019. (on or around). Two alleged armed robbers have been set alight by community members in Ntcheu.
21 October 2019 (on or around). Truck drivers demonstrated in Lilongwe, demanding higher salaries. [size=50].
21 October 2019 (on or around). Truck drivers demonstrated in Blantyre, demanding higher salaries. [size=50].

21 October 2019. The house of human rights defender and coordinator at the Human Rights Consultative Committee (HRCC), Reverend McDonald Sembereka, was attacked in Nyewa, in the city of Lilongwe. Five unknown men fired gunshots at the house and threw petrol bombs in front of the house. The armed men shouted death threats.

22 October 2019. The Chikulamayembe headquarters at Bolero in Rumphi was set alight over chieftaincy disputes by supporters of Joseph Bongololo Gondwe, who wants to be named chief. The vehicle of Senior chief Kawazamawe, who is a senior adviser to the Chikulamayembe chieftaincy has also been stoned.

25 October 2019. MEC commissioners were blocked and stoned during a campaign. 13 houses have been set alight and people sustained injuries. The violence was sparked by the DPP allegedly buying votes through registering voters for loans Ndaula Primary School. A chairman was beaten up by bystanders. 16 people have been arrested. Parliamentary by-election campaign in Lilongwe South Constituency has been postponed due to violence and vote buying.

25 October 2019. Women, under the banner of the WMM, marched against sexual violence against women and girls in Msundwe, Lilongwe. The march was in response to sexual violence against women and girls, two weeks ago at Msundwe, Mpingu and M'bwatalika by police officers. [size=no report]

28 October 2019. Students, led by Musrec and staff demonstrated at the Mzuzu University to demanda that management address fee balances that block students from writing exams, and teachers are demanding their allowances. Police fired teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].

28 October 2019. Riots have been reported at the Lunzu Secondary School in Blantyre. Students have damaged various structures at the school, houses belonging to teachers, and one student has been injured. [size=no report].
29 October 2019. Students from the M'manga Community Day Secondary School in Balaka demonstrated on the M1 road against the school banning girls from wearing a hijab. [size=no report].

01 November 2019 (on or around). Two men have been killed by community members in the Neno District. The community members accused the men of bewitching a snake to kill a 19 year old man. [size=no report]

01 November 2019 (on or around). Residents stormed the Chilobwe Police Unit in Blantyre, demanding the release of a suspect who killed a boy after a break in. Demonstrators broke windows at the police station. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].
02 November 2019. Relatives of a woman who was killed by a man in Nkhata Bay, went to the suspects' neighbourhood and burnt down seven houses.

04 November 2019. Members of the Anglican church clashed with Muslim community members in M'manga, near Blantyre, after some young men snatched the hijabs off girls passing the church. Some windows of a mosque and the local priest's home were smashed, and three people were hurt during the incident.

05 November 2019. Residents from Dedza gathered at the police station, demanding that police release a man suspected of kidnapping a child. The demonstrators damaged a police unit. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report].

17 November 2019. A mob damaged a car and the house of a nurse from the Bowe Health Centre in Dowa after a pregnant woman died at the centre due to not being assisted. Police arrived and used teargas to disperse the mob. [size=no report]

20 November 2019. Vendors demonstrated in Lilongwe and barricaded the M1 road with burning tyres in Lilongwe. The demonstrators accused street vendors of spoiling their businesses. Street vendors in return also demonstrated against vendors. [size=no report].
20 November 2019 (on or around). A mob killed an elderly couple and assaulted another person, accusing them of killing a boy through witchcraft in Ntchisi. [size=no report]
On 28 November 2019, unemployed healthcare workers demonstrated in Ntcheu, demanding more healthcare workers to be employed. [size=no report].
On 3 December 2019, a mob in Kasungu killed a suspected thief. [size=no report]
On 04 December 2019, pregnant women demonstrated at the Kasungu District Hospital, demanding better service delivery. [size=no report].
On 5 December 2019, a mob destroyed seven houses in Blantyre to demonstrate over the killing of a community member. [size=no report]
On 6 December 2019, shop workers in Mzuzu demonstrated against low wages. [size=no report].

column7: HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition; Lawyers (Malawi)
column17: On 10 December 2019, a march, organised by HRDC, was reported in Lilongwe. The march was in celebration of the International Human Rights Day. [size=no report].

Around 15 December 2019 (month of), 4 people were killed and around 21 houses burnt in the Nkhata Bay district (Northern) during clashes between villages in traditional authorities of Mkumbira and Timbiri over suspected stolen property. [size=no report]

On 16 December 2019, police used teargas to disperse a group of people who are demanding justice against a man suspected of theft in the area of Nkhamenya, near Kasungu. The crows carried catapults, stones and panga knives and burnt down a police unit. [size=no report].

On 20 December 2019 (on or around), police used teargas to disperse a group of people demanding justice against a man suspected of theft in the area of Kasunga (also known as Kasungu). [size=no report].

On 20 December 2019, locals looted the shop of Burundian refugees in Kasungu after the body of a girl was found with bite marks. Community members accused a Burundian's dog of biting the girl. Police intervened. [size=no report].
On 24 December 2019, women marched in Karonga to march against bicycle operators accused of undressing women wearing trousers and miniskirts. [size=no report].
On 26 December 2019, three people were killed by community members in Lupembe, Karonga, accusing the victims of practising witchcraft. [size=no report].
On 28 December 2019, community members killed two people after they found them allegedly stealing goats in the Mbewa Village, near Lilongwe. [size=no report].
On 08 January 2020, a man was fatality beaten by a mob for being suspected of theft in Mzuzu. [size=no report].

On or around the 08 January 2020, three journalists were arrested at the Kamuzu International Airport in Lilongwe while covering the return of the European Electoral observer mission. The journalists were first charged with conduct likely to cause breach of the peace but were later changed the charge to disorderly conduct under the Aviation Act.

On 08 January 2020, employees of a store in Limbe demonstrated outside the store after a man committed suicide after he was dismissed for stealing milk. Running battles between police and demonstrators were reported. [size=no report].

On 09 January 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Lilongwe, denouncing violence and rape against women by police officers. The demonstrators are demanding the arrest of the officers accused of raping women. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. Police arrested 17 people for public violence. [size=thousands]

On 10 January 2020, demonstrators assaulted a female journalist during a march to hand over a memorandum demanding the removal of the government tax collecting body, officers at Mbilima Border Post and to upgrade a road that connects Chitipa Boma, the border post and Tanzania. Shops were also looted during the handover. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]
On 10 January 2020, demonstrators damaged a waste management facility in Mzuzu, accusing city authorities of not being able to safely manage garbage. [size=no report].

On 10 January 2020, Chitipa residents demonstrated at the Malawi Revenue Authority (MRA) offices in Blantyre, demanding the MRA to remove the officers at the Mbilima Border Post and an upgrade of the road that connects the Chitipa Boma border post and Tanzania. A journalist was assaulted during the demonstration. [size=no report].
On 11 January 2020, a mob killed a woman Chitipa, accusing her of bewitching her granddaughter after she failed to attend her granddaughters' funeral. [size=no report].
On 14 January 2020 (on or around), city council workers gathered at the council offices in Blantyre, demanding a salary increase. [size=no report].

On 15 January 2020, demonstrators in Chitipa vandalised and ransacked some of the shops, also barricading roads with burning tyres. Police arrested 18 demonstrators for public violence. No reason for the demonstrations was reported. [size=no report].

On 16 January 2020, demonstration action, led by HRDC, has been reported in Blantyre over alleged bribery attempts to judges presiding over the disputed presidential election case and the cases against police officers in Msundwe accused of sexual violence. A truck carrying HRDC sound systems were set alight by suspected regime supporters in Blantyre during the nationwide strike. [size=no report].

On 16 January 2020, members of the Muslim community in Machinga demonstrated, demanding the arrest of people who killed a police officer last year October during a violent demonstration. [size=no report].

On 16 January 2020, demonstration action, led by HRDC, has been reported in Zomba over alleged bribery attempts to judges presiding over the disputed presidential election case and the cases against police officers in Msundwe accused of sexual violence. [size=no report].

On 16 January 2020, demonstration action, led by HRDC, has been reported in Lilongwe over alleged bribery attempts to judges presiding over the disputed presidential election case and the cases against police officers in Msundwe accused of sexual violence. Demonstrators handed over a petition to the Anti-Corruption Bureau offices, demanding arrest of those involved in the cases and demanding the resignation of the Malawi Electoral Commission chairperson. [size=50000].

On 16 January 2020, demonstration action, led by HRDC, has been reported in Mzuzu over alleged bribery attempts to judges presiding over the disputed presidential election case and the cases against police officers in Msundwe accused of sexual violence. Police used rubber bullets to disperse demonstrators who stormed the police station and arrested two demonstrators for public violence. [size=no report].
On 18 January 2020, ADMARC security officials fired at people in Nkhwazi Trading Centre in Mchinji when a truck carrying maize to Thyolo was stormed by community members. [size=no report]
On or around 20 January 2020, thousands of teachers were joined by students during a demonstration over delayed salary payments for teachers in Blantyre, Zomba, and Dedza. [size=thousands]
On or around 20 January 2020, thousands of teachers were joined by students during a demonstration over delayed salary payments for teachers in Blantyre, Zomba, and Dedza. [size=thousands]
On 20 January 2020, teachers marched to the officers of the District Education Manager in Lilongwe, demanding their December salaries. [size=no report].
On or around 20 January 2020, thousands of teachers were joined by students during a demonstration over delayed salary payments for teachers in Blantyre, Zomba, and Dedza. [size=thousands]

On 21 January 2020, students demonstrated in Dowa in demonstration over teachers being on strike due to delayed salary payments. Demonstrators looted shops. Police arrested 22 demonstrators. [size=at least 22].

On 21 January 2020, teachers demonstrated in Balaka, demanding the payment of their December salaries and to be added on the payroll after they were removed because the department said they didn't submit the necessary document. [size=no report].

On or around 21 January 2020, students pelted vehicles with stones during a march to Mponela to meet education authorities who they accused of not paying their striking teachers for December. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds. [size=no report].

On 21 January 2020, students demonstrated in Mzuzu in demonstration over teachers being on strike due to delayed salary payments. Police officers used teargas canisters to disperse learners who tried to invade Northern Region Police Headquarters. [size=no report].
On 22 January 2020, learners demonstrated in Karonga in support of teachers, demanding their salaries that were not paid in December. A district commissioners office was set alight. [size=no report]
On 23 January 2020, teachers marched to Capital Hill, Lilongwe, demanding their December salaries that have not been paid. [size=no report].
On 26 January 2020, a group of women beat and undressed a woman, accusing her of spreading false information in Mzuzu. [size=no report]
On 27 January 2020, city council workers barricaded roads with stones, trees and burning tyres during a demonstration in Lilongwe, demanding a salary increase. [size=no report]
On 28 January 2020, demonstrators marched to the district commissioner office, demanding the Senior Chief Ngabu to be re-appointed after he was dismissed in December last year. [size=no report]

column7: Women (Malawi); YFN: Young Feminists Network; Pepeta Africa
column17: On 01 February 2020, the Young Feminists Network together with PEPETA Network marched to the Parliament Building in Lilongwe against violence against women. [size=no report]
On February 5 2020, residents looted shops in Lilongwe, Central, that belonged to Burundian nationals. Police officers fired tear gas to disperse them. [size=no report]

On or around 05 February 2020, residents of the Traditional Authority Chiwere (Dowa chosen as location) demonstrated against the appointment of the new Senior Chief following death of Senior Chief Chiwere last year. [size=no report]
On 12 February 2020, demonstrators, led by the HRDC, gathered at the Chichiri Upper Stadium in Blantyre, in the southern region, demanding the MEC chairperson to resign. [size=no report]

On 13 February 2020, demonstrators, led by the HRDC, marched in Mangochi to the Mangochi Town Council offices to present a petition, demanding the immediate resignation of the MEC chairperson and the commissioners. [size=no report]

On 13 February 2020, demonstrators, led by the HRDC, marched in Zomba to the MEC offices to present a petition, demanding the immediate resignation of the MEC chairperson and the commissioners. [size=no report]

On 13 February 2020, around a thousand of demonstrators, led by the HRDC, marched to the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) offices in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) and locked the offices with chains and padlocks. The demonstrators are demanding the MEC chairwoman to step down. [size=around a thousand]

On 13 February 2020, around 5000 demonstrators, led by the HRDC, marched to the Malawi Electoral Commission (MEC) offices in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) and locked the offices with chains and padlocks. The demonstrators are demanding the MEC chairwoman to step down. The demonstrators handed the keys to a military officer. [size=around 5000]

On 13 February 2020, hundreds of demonstrators, led by the HRDC, marched in Mzuzu, to the MEC offices. Some demonstrators threw stones at police. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=hundreds]

On 15 February 2020, a woman living with albinism was attacked in Mzimba (Mzimba, Northern) and one of her toes were removed by two men who took the body part to a herbalist. All three men have been arrested.

On 17 February 2020, members of the DPP marched in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) to challenge the Constitution Court judgement that nullified last year's presidential election results. [size=no report]

On 17 February, running battles between police and demonstrators, including taxi operators, butchers, consumers and developers, have been reported in Mzimba (Mzimba, Northern), during a demonstration over grievances with the district council. [size=no report]
On 18 February 2020, members of the DPP marched in Zomba (Zomba, Southern) to challenge the Constitution Court judgement that nullified last year's presidential election results. [size=no report]
On or around 25 February 2020, a mob set alight and killed a woman suspected of killing her grandson in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern). [size=no report]
On or around 25 February 2020, students from the Malawi College of Accountancy in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) demonstrated over the delayed release of exam results. [size=no report]

column7: DPP: Democratic Progressive Party; UDF: United Democratic Forum
column17: On 26 February 2020, thousands of DPP and UDF supporters marched in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) to hand over a petition relating to the court decision in early February to nullify the 21 May 2019 presidential election results. [size=thousands]

On 26 February 2020, DPP supporters marched in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern), demonstrating against the court decision in early February to nullify the 21 May 2019 presidential election results. [size=no report]

On 26 February 2020, DPP supporters marched in Zomba (Zomba, Southern), demonstrating against the court decision in early February to nullify the 21 May 2019 presidential election results. [size=no report]
On 26 February 2020, a mob attacked a man suspected of theft in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern). Police intervened before the mob could set him alight. [size=no report]

column7: DPP: Democratic Progressive Party; UDF: United Democratic Forum
column17: On 28 February 2020, residents of Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) pelted stones at DPP members who marched in the streets against the court decision in early February to nullified the 21 May 2019 presidential election results. [size=no report]

On 28 February 2020, villagers assaulted African Parks Malawi rangers and set alight their vehicles in Bamba Village and pelted stones at police at Mpamantha Village near Nkhotakota (Nkhotakota, Central) after a woman was killed by an elephant. [size=no report]
On 2 March 2020, about 90 demonstrators, mostly women, marched in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) against sexual violence against women. [size=about 90]

column7: DPP: Democratic Progressive Party; UDF: United Democratic Forum
column17: On or around 4 March 2020, hundreds of DPP and UDF supporters marched in Mangochi (Mangochi, Southern) to hand over a petition to the district commissioner relating to the Constitutional Court ruling which nullified the May 21 2019 presidential election. [size=hundreds]
On 8 March 2020, women staged a protest march in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern), supporting international women's day celebrations. [size=no report]
On 8 March 2020, women staged a protest march in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern), supporting the international women's day celebrations. [size=no report]

On 10 March 2020, demonstrators accompanied the chairperson of the HRDC to the police station in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) and demanded the release of two HRDC members who were arrested the previous day. Demonstrators pelted stones at police. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]
On 11 March 2020, residents in Mangochi (Mangochi, Southern) marched to show support for the government over the arrest of HRDC members. [size=no report]
On 12 March 2020, HRDC supporters demonstrated in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern), demanding the release of arrested HRDC leaders. [size=no report]

On 18 March 2020, street vendors marched to the civic offices in Zomba (Zomba, Southern) to demonstrate against the city authorities for victimizing them and damaging their properties. [size=no report]

On 19 March 2020, over 500 people from Namuyemba Community, Traditional Authority (T/A) Mwaulambia, armed with axes and pangas, marched to the police station in Chitipa Boma (Chitipa, Northern), demanding that police hand over two men accused of killing a security guard. Police fired teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=over 500]
On or around 22 March 2020, two people suspected of being ""blood suckers"" were killed in the Kasungu District (Central). No one was arrested in connection with the murders. [size=no report]

column16: Nyasa Times (Malawi); Face of Malawi; Malawi24; Malawi Times
column17: On or around 23 March 2020, two Zambian nationals were burned to death in Ilomba and Navitengo villages in Chitipa district (Northern) accused of being ""blood suckers"". [size=no report]

column16: Malawi24; Nyasa Times (Malawi); Malawi Times; Face of Malawi
column17: On or around 23 March 2020, a person was killed by a mob in Mzimba district (Nothern) accused of being ""blood suckers"". [size=no report]
On 26 March 2020, a man was burnt to death by a mob in Thyolo (Southern). The victim was attacked for stealing maize in the area. [size=no report]

On 27 March 2020, a vehicle was set on fire after three people travelling in it were accused of being blood suckers on the Kasungu-Nkhotakota road (Kasungu, Central). The victims were stopped by an illegal roadblock placed by local community but they managed to escape. [size=no report]
On 28 March 2020, a mob killed 2 people in Kasungu (Kasungu, Central) for allegedly hiding blood suckers. [size=no report]

On or before 30 March 2020, MCP members allegedly targeted DPP leaders and attacked villagers looking to benefit from Malawi Enterprises Development Fund Limited (Medf) loans in Dedza and Lilongwe districts (Lilongwe, Central). No fatalities reported. [size=no report]

On 30 March 2020, rioters stoned and torched Malomo police station in Ntchisi in Ntchisi (Dowa, Central) after the officers rescued a man accused of being a ""blood sucker"" from an attack. No fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

On 30 March 2020, 3 medical workers who were in possession of medical equipment used to collect blood samples were attacked by a mob in Mchinji (Mchinji, Central) accusing them of being blood suckers. [size=no report]

On 03 April 2020, rioters stormed the office of the District Commissioner in the area of Traditional Authority (TA) Kachere in Dedza district (Dedza, Central), accusing the commissioner of selling their land to the Dedza District Council. [size=no report]
On 05 April 2020, rioters beat two Mozambicans to death in Karonga district (Karonga, Northern), accusing them of being transmitters of the coronavirus. [size=no report]

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the children of a village headman demolished the house of another man in Zele village (Rumphi, Northern) as the man was accused of bewitching their father. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Mangochi (Mangochi, Southern) by traders and women against the coronavirus lockdown. They headed to the District Commissioner's office carrying placards of protests and singing anti-lockdown songs. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Mzuzu (Mzimb, Northern). The protests were started by business people, mostly vendors, who took to the streets opposing the 21-day Coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) by business people, mostly vendors, who took to the streets against the 21-day Coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, vendors marched to the Civic Office in Zomba (Zomba, Southern), where they demanded clarification on the council's decision to close down the main market during the Coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, Malawi police used teargas to disperse violent demonstrators, who were attacking shops at the business square in Kasungu (Kasungu, Central). The riots were started by business people, mostly vendors, who took to the streets opposing the 21-day Coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Karonga (Karonga, Northern) by business people, mostly vendors, who took to the streets to opposing the 21-day Coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020, business people held a peaceful demonstration in Ndirande (Blantyre, Southern) and presented their petition to the council. The protests were started by business people, mostly vendors, took to the streets opposing the 21-day Coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 20 April 2020, junior staff at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital held a sit in demonstration in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) against the critical shortage of equipment for Coronavirus treatment and demanding an increase of their monthly risk allowance. Healthcare workers chanted anti-government songs while carrying placards in their premises. [size=no report]

column7: Police Forces of Malawi (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On 24 April 2020, prison guards in Malawi lit bonfires and pelted the police with stones in a violent demonstration at Chichiri prison in Blantyre (Southern) against the lack of personal protective equipment for the Coronavirus and additional pay for hazardous work. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Malawi (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On 24 April 2020, armed prison guards and police clashed at a correctional facility in Zomba (Zomba, Southern). The guards had been opposing the lack of personal protective equipment for the Coronavirus and additional pay for hazardous work. No fatalities were reported.

column7: Police Forces of Malawi (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On 24 April 2020, rioting prison guards in Malawi pelted police vehicles with stones during a violent demonstration in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) against the lack of personal protective equipment for the Coronavirus and additional pay for hazardous work. [size=no report]

column7: Police Forces of Malawi (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On 24 April 2020, prison guards in Malawi lit bonfires and pelted the police with stones during a violent demonstration in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) against the lack of personal protective equipment for the Coronavirus and additional pay for hazardous work. [size=no report]

On 26 April 2020, junior staff at the Nkhotakota District Hospital held a sit in demonstration in Nkhotakota (Nkhotakota, Central) against the critical shortage of equipment for Coronavirus treatment and demanding an increase of their monthly risk allowance. Healthcare workers chanted anti-government songs while carrying placards in their premises. [size=no report]

column16: Maravi Express; Nyasa Times (Malawi); Maravi Post
column17: On 1 May 2020, a group of employees of an energy supply company were attacked by 8 men in Kasitu (Nkhotakota, Central). The perpetrators accused the group of being ""blood suckers""; they were arrested and sentenced to 3 years in jail on 10 September 2020. It was not reported whether the group was injured. [size=8]

On 1 May 2020, Electricity Supply Corporation of Malawi employees were attacked by a vigilante group in Kasitu (Nkhotakota, Central) at night when they were travelling to work on a faulty transmission power line. The community members ambushed the workers accusing them of being blood-suckers. [size=no report]
On 2 May 2020, a group of people attacked a man thought to be an electoral monitor for the MCP in Mulange (Mulanje, Southern).

On 2 May 2020, residents held a violent demonstration in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) against the decision to use the Luwinga Technical Centre as a coronavirus isolation facility. The demonstrators burned beds and mattresses and pelted stones at the police. [size=no report]
On 2 May 2020, supporters of the opposition UTM were assaulted by unknown people in Mulanje (Mulanje, Southern). The attacked was allegedly politically-motivated.
On 2 May 2020, supporters of the opposition UTM were assaulted by unknown people in Thyolo (Thyolo, Southern). The attack was allegedly politically-motivated.
On 2 May 2020, opposition MCP party members allegedly beat DPP monitors and the party's district head in Dowa (Central). [size=no report]
On 3 May 2020, petrol bomb was hurled into the house of the opposition UTM's Eastern Region Director of Women and her party vehicle was also torched by unknown people in Balaka (Balaka, Southern).
On 4 May 2020, a DPP youth militia, known as the Cadets, allegedly torched UTM offices in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) using petrol bombs. 3 people died following the attack.
On 7 May 2020, a mob attacked the house of a 27-year-old man who escaped a coronavirus isolation centre in Ngonga near Nkhata Bay (Nkhata Bay, Northern). [size=no report]
On 7 May 2020, 7 people have been charged for stoning the convoy of Malawi's president Peter Mutharika in Ndirande (Blantyre, Southern). [size=at least 7]

column7: MCP: Malawi Congress Party; UTM: United Transformation Movement
column17: On 8 May 2020, supporters of Malawi's opposition forces (UTM and MCP) took to the streets chanting anti-Mutharika songs in Lilongwe (Central) after the supreme court ruled in favor of carrying out fresh presidential elections on 2 July. [size=no report]

On 12 May 2020, support staff at the Rumphi District Hospital (Rumphi, Northern) held a sit-in demonstration against the government's decision to leave some workers out of the list of those receiving risk allowances amid the coronavirus outbreak. [size=no report]

On 15 May 2020, a mob burned the houses and vehicles of a businessman in Mangochi (Mangochi, Southern) after two children of his neighbor were found dead in his car. The local people allege that they were 'murdered for rituals' of the businessman. [size=no report]
Around 15 May 2020 (month of), a group attacked health workers in Ndirande (Blantyre, Southern) as they buried a coronavirus victim at the Malabada Cemetery. No reports on injures. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Malawi); RTMU: Reformed Timber Millers Union
column17: Around 20 May 2020 (week of), members of Reformed Timber Millers Union demonstrated in Chikangawa (Mzimba, Northern) by blocking vehicles of foreign companies from entering and leaving the forest. They aimed to get the government to allocate a concession area and trees to them for timber harvesting in the Chikangawa Forest. [size=no report]
On 29 May 2020, a group of people pelted stones at Tonse Alliance members during a political rally in Liwonde (Machinga, Southern). [size=no report]
On 29 May 2020, the convoy of Malawi's vice president was pelted with stones by a group of people as he conducted an election campaign tour in Mulanje district (Southern). [size=no report]

column16: Face of Malawi; Malawi News Agency
column17: On 31 May 2020, a village headman accused of witchcraft was set on fire and killed by four people in the Kachiwaya village near Dowa (Dowa, Central). The group also torched houses and damaged belongings of the victim. The 4 perpetrators were arrested. [size=4]

On 3 June 2020, workers at the Pharmacy, Medicines and Poisons Board staged a sit-in protest in Lilongwe (Central) over poor management by the Board. They demanded that the Director General of the Board be removed. [size=no report]

column7: UDF: United Democratic Forum; DPP: Democratic Progressive Party
column17: On 5 June 2020, suspected United Democratic Front (UDF) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) functionaries blocked Bakili Muluzi Highway near Machinga (Southern) with logs and burned tyres to stop the vice president's motorcade from passing. [size=no report]

column9: Government of Malawi (2014-); DPP: Democratic Progressive Party
column17: On 8 June 2020, the Political Affairs Adviser of the President of Malawi was pelted with stones and wounded in Gawamadzi village in the area of Traditional Authority Chiwere in Dowa district (Central) while he was holding a pre-election rally. [size=no report]

On 10 June 2020, the linesmen of the Electricity Supply Corporation of Malawi staged a peaceful demonstration in Mzuzu (Mzimba) to demand promotions, risk allowances as well as unpaid salary arrears. [size=no report]

On 10 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Mzuzu (Northern) to push the National Assembly to discuss and pass the electoral reform bills that were rejected by the president of Malawi. Human Right Defenders Coalition led the demonstration. [size=no report]

On 10 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Lilongwe (Central) to push the National Assembly to discuss and pass the electoral reform bills, which were rejected by the president of Malawi. Human Right Defenders Coalition led the demonstration. [size=no report]

On 14 June 2020, 11 health workers and an ambulance driver were beaten and injured by a mob in Ndirande (Blantyre, Southern). The health workers were burying a coronavirus victim at the Malabada Cemetery when the group arrived demanding evidence that the individual had died from coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 17 June 2020, Malawian lawyers staged a peaceful demonstration in Lilongwe (Central) and demanded judiciary independence from the government. [size=no report]
On 17 June 2020, lawyers and citizens held a peaceful demonstration in Blantyre (Southern) against the interference of the executive body of the government. [size=no report]
On 17 June 2020, lawyers and some citizens held a peaceful demonstration in Zomba (Southern) against the interference of the executive body of the government. [size=no report]
On 17 June 2020, lawyers and some citizens held a peaceful demonstration in Mzuzu (Northern) against the interference of the executive body of the government. [size=no report]

On 23 June 2020, the Tonse Alliance allegedly assaulted election monitors for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Lilongwe (Lilongwe). A female monitor, who was assaulted on the day, died a few days later and 15 other monitors are still missing.

On 2 July 2020, Kameza Quarantine Centre frontline health workers demonstrated in Blantyre City Council (Southern) offices, demanding their risk allowances in excess of K48 million Kwacha. [size=no report]

column16: Face of Malawi; Malawi24; Maravi Post
column17: On 6 July 2020, a man was beaten to death by a group of people in Kalaundi village, Chikwawa (Chikwawa, Southern) after he was caught stealing fresh beans. [size=no report]

Around 7 July 2020 (as reported), security officers from the Agricultural Development and Marketing Corporation (ADMARC) gathered in front of the agency regional officer in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) to demand the payment of late overtime hours. The group is on strike. [size=no report]
On 7 July 2020, about 100 cotton farmers gathered in the District Council offices in Balaka (Balaka, Southern) to demand their payment. [size=about 100]
Around 14 July 2020 (as reported), a woman was killed by three people who suspected the victim of bewitching her granddaughter. The perpetrators where identified, but not arrested. [size=3]

On 14 July 2020, a man was chased and killed by residents of Lusimbo village, Rumphi (Northern), after he was accused by a witch finder of bewitching his sister-in-law, who died the previous month. [size=no report]
Around 15 July 2020 (month of), a group beat and injured a man in Mzimba district after he was accused of stealing bags of tobacco. [size=no report]

column7: DPP: Democratic Progressive Party; UDF: United Democratic Forum
column17: On 15 July 2020, a broadcast cameraperson was beaten by supporters of the DDP and UDF whilst the group was in front of the Lolongwe court (Lilongwe) to support former president Peter Mutharika's head of security during a hearing. [size=no report]

On 17 July 2020, a group took the streets and closed the District Health Office of Likoma (Likoma District, Northern), accusing the district's director of health and social services of misuse of funds, among others. [size=no report]
On 22 July 2020, district council employees blocked the doors of the Nkhotakota district council (Nkhotakota Boma, Central) in a demonstration against the non-payment of wages. [size=no report]
On 24 July 2020, a woman with albinism was abducted by unidentified individuals in Molipa Village near Kawinga (Machinga, Southern). The victim managed to escape.

On 25 July 2020, the police arrested the former director of National Intelligence Services and the former State House chief ICT officer in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) for involvement in planting secret devices in office of the president.
On 28 July 2020, a man was beaten to death by a mob in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) after he tried to steal money from a mobile agent. [size=no report]

On 29 July 2020, more than 70 villagers threw stones at health workers in the village of Phangwa near Nkhotakota (Nkhotakota, Central) during the burial of a woman who died from the coronavirus. The villagers were accusing the health workers of faking her diagnosis; the woman suffered from an unknown condition for three years. [size=more than 70]

On 31 July 2020, Zimbabweans and supporters gathered in front of the Zimbabwe Embassy in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) in a demonstration against state capture, corruption, and human rights abuses, among other things. [size=no report]

On 3 August 2020, family members of a coronavirus victim attacked health workers in Likoma (Likoma District, Northern), when they attempted to collect blood samples from the group, accusing them of spreading false information regarding the virus. No reports on injuries; no one was arrested. [size=no report]
On 7 August 2020, a man was beaten to death by a mob in Balaka (Balaka, Southern) after he was caught attempting to steal a solar panel from the roof of the house. [size=no report]

column16: Malawi24; Malawi Times; Face of Malawi
column17: On 9 August 2020, a group of villagers pelted stones at a man in Mbuta (TA Msakambera, Dowa), accusing the man of having bewitched and killed another person in 2017. The man fled to the police station. The group set his as well as the houses of his relatives on fire, also looting items. [size=no report]

Around 12 August 2020 (week of), a prophet of the Christ Kingdom Healing and Deliverance Ministries was beaten and injured by congregates during a service in Mchinji (Mchinji, Central) after he demanded more money for the church, insisting that 2020 has been a good year. [size=no report]

column16: Face of Malawi; Maravi Post; Malawi24; Malawi Times
column17: On 15 August 2020, a former soldier was beaten to death near the Guillime Trading Centre, Minchi (Mchinji, Central) after being accused of sexually assaulting a child on 31 July 2020. Once he appeared in the area, he was assaulted by the child's father, who was severely injured by him, before the mob attacked him. [size=no report]

Around 16 August 2020 (as reported), a group destroyed 19 houses, looted goods, and ordered the residents to leave the land in the Jefitala Village, in the TA Chitekwere (Lilongwe, Central). The event is motivated by land disputes; 8 people and a Village Head were arrested.

column16: Malawi Times; Capital Radio Malawi; Nation (Malawi); Malawi24; Maravi Post
column17: On 17 August 2020, hundreds of taxi drivers drove in the streets of Lilongwe City (Central) in a demonstration against fines imposed for traffic violations, and for being banned from operating within the city. [size=hundreds]
On 17 August 2020, a man was beaten to death by a mob near the Thavita Trading Centre, Salima (Salima, Central) after he was caught stealing a battery from a motor vehicle. [size=no report]

column16: Capital Radio Malawi; Face of Malawi
column17: Around 18 August 2020 (as reported), a group of Muslims destroyed a billboard of the Good Samaritan Church in Zomba (Zomba, Southern). The event took place as ongoing discussions over a disagreement on an Islamic Bureau billboard, which was deemed distasteful by some Christians, was happening. [size=no report]

Around 19 August 2020 (as reported), four women were set on fire by a mob in Mulanje (Mulanje, Southern) over accusations of killing a 20-year-old man through magic. One of the victims died on 19 August 2020. [size=no report]

On 23 August 2020, community members, including village heads, beat and injured a Senior Chief and 4 Mchinji District Council officials in Tikoliwe (Mchinji, Central) during a meeting to present plans to allocate land for a Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) border market. About 100 people participated in the meeting and accused the officers of being corrupt. The group also destroyed a vehicle belonging to the Chief and took their mobile phones. [size=no report]
On 24 August 2020, a man was burnt to death by a mob in Nsanje (Nsanje, Southern), after he and other individuals severely injured a man during an alleged robbery. [size=no report]

On 24 August 2020, a DPP councilor was shot and injured by officers of the Road's Authority in Chikwawa (Chikwawa, Southern). The victim was shot during the gathering of the RA with people affected by the construction the Thabwa - Seven Chitseko Fatima Road for the payment of compensation. Disagreements over the amount of the benefit led authorities to open fire against the group. [size=no report]

On 29 August 2020, a man was burnt to death by a mob in Magombo (Ntcheu, Central). The victim, together with another man, robbed a motorcycle rider on 27 August 2020 and was being chased by the owner of the vehicle, followed by a group. The other man was arrested. The victim had recently left prison due to the coronavirus epidemic. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, a person was killed and around 25 houses burnt in the Nkhata Bay district (Northern) during inter-village fights over land issues and was also reported on the following day (coded separately). [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, a group threw stones at the police as they used tear gas to disperse a demonstration in Mulanje (Mulanje, Southern). The demonstration was against plans of a company to transform a soccer field into an estate. Tires were set on fire and police cars were destroyed. No reports on injuries; 11 people were arrested. [size=at least 11]
On 31 August 2020, a person was killed and around 25 houses burnt in the Nkhata Bay district (Northern) during inter-village fights over land issues and started on the previous day. [size=no report]

column16: Capital Radio Malawi; Face of Malawi
column17: On 1 September 2020, the police used tear gas to disperse a demonstration of minibus operators on the Masauko Chipembere Highway (Blantyre, Southern). The group was demonstrating against what they deemed oppressive coronavirus-related measures: reducing capacity by 60 percent, the number of fees and arrests made by the traffic police, among other things. [size=no report]
On 1 September 2020, a man was stoned to death by a mob in Dedza (Dedza, Central). The group accused the victim of bewitching a man who died in South Africa. No one was arrested. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, a woman was stoned to death and a man was stoned and severely injured by a mob in Gowoke village, near Linthipe (Dedza, Central) after the two allegedly robbed a motorcycle close to the village. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, a mob tried to invade the house of a Chief in Molande village, near Thyolo (Thyolo, Southern). An elder had sought refuge in the house after being accused of witchcraft after a boy died drowned. The police were called, used tear gas to disperse the group, and rescued the elder. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, 2 people were stoned to death by a mob in the Goliati Trading Centre in Thyolo (Thyolo, Southern) after an attempted robbery of a motorcycle. The two were taken to the police station, but a group of individuals took them out of the establishment. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, 36 demonstrators were stopped by the police from marching to the Capital Hill, Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) for a vigil to demand compensation for the stampede at Bingu National Stadium in 2017, when 8 children were killed and 27 people were injured. The police stopped the march stating that the group only had authorization for a petition delivery, not a vigil. [size=36]

On 11 September 2020, flea market vendors gathered at the MCP (Malawi Congress Party) Regional Headquarters for the North, in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) to present a petition to the MCP over the alleged unfair distribution of market space at Mzuzu Flea Market. [size=no report]
On 17 September 2020, a man was burnt to death by a mob in Zele village near Rumphi (Rumphi, Northern) over accusations of bewitching a village headman in April 2020. [size=no report]
On 20 September 2020, a man was beaten to death and set on fire by a mob in Namasaloma village (Mulanje, Southern) after he stole the mobile phone of a woman. [size=no report]

On 20 September 2020, a group killed a man and injured another in a forest area of Suzi (Salina, Central) after the two allegedly stole goats. The owner of the goat and other people went to look for the goats and upon finding them, attacked them. [size=no report]
On 21 September 2020, a man was beaten to death by a mob in Mulanje (Mulanje, Southern) after he attacked another individual. 4 people were arrested. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, a group looted the shop of a Burundi national in Rumphi (Rumphi, Northern) after villagers asked the man not to operate in the area due to previous accusations of employee mistreatment. 2 people were arrested. [size= no report]

On 22 September 2020, a man was beaten by a mob in the Jumbi area, TA Chikulamayembe of Rumphi district (Northern) under accusations of having bewitched his uncle, who died of alcohol poisoning. The man's house and grocery shop were also destroyed. [size=no report]

On 23 September 2020, a mob stoned a Bolero police unit in Rumphi (Rumphi, Northern) to demand the release of two people who were arrested on 21 September for looting the shop of a Burundi national. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, a group took a coffin with a body to the Malawi Revenue Authority (MRA) in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) in a demonstration against what they believe was a harassment by the part of the MRA officers that caused the death of the man in the coffin (the man died of hypertension following misunderstandings with officials concerning taxes for his goods in the border). [size=no report]

On 26 September 2020, 2 men were shot and killed by forest scouts in the Thuma Forest Reserve. Moments later, residents of the Chigumula and Mpango villages (Dedza, Central) tried to assist their colleagues, but the scouts opened fire against the them, injuring 4 other people.

On 29 September 2020, residents from 5 villages destroyed over 10 houses in the village of Nanthowa (Dedza, Central). The villages surround the Thuma forest, where there are ongoing clashes over the boundary of the forest and the surrounding villages.
Around 3 October 2020 (between 3 and 4 October), 2 men accused of attempted theft were killed by a mob in the Maning'a village (Mulanje, Southern). The bodies were set on fire. [size=no report]

On 4 October 2020, a group set 5 houses on fire and damaged a mill in the Katope area, Mzimba (Mzimba) to avenge an attack to a villager beaten in July, accused of stealing bags of tobacco (coded separately, July 2020). 2 people were arrested; no reports on injuries.
Around 5 October 2020 (as reported), a group stoned a man accused of theft to death as he was being taken to Mayani (Dedza, Central). [size=no report]

On 6 October 2020, a group, led by gulewamkulu dancers, vandalized a police unit near Dowa (Dedza, Central), demanding a known criminal to be released to them. The police used tear gas to disperse the group. [size=no report]
Around 6 October 2020 (between 6 and 7 October), a man accused of theft was killed by a mob in Mulanje (Mulanje, Southern). [size=no report]
On 7 October 2020, a mob killed a man suspected of theft and set his body on fire in a village near Mangochi (Mangochi, Southern). [size=no report]

On 8 October 2020, truck drivers took to the streets in Karonga (Karonga, Northern), in demonstration against majority of Malawi's oils being hauled into the country in tankers belonging to Tanzanians. [size=no report]

column7: Women (Malawi); Women's Manifesto Movement; HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition
column16: Nation (Malawi); Nyasa Times (Malawi); Malawi24; Maravi Post; Malawi Times; Capital Radio Malawi
column17: On 9 October 2020, women, led by the Women's Manifesto Movement and the HRDC, took to the streets in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) in a demonstration against the President who, they say, promotes a system that oppresses women in the country, and to demand the fulfillment of the Gender Equality Act. [size=no report]

column7: Women (Malawi); Women's Manifesto Movement; HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition
column16: Maravi Post; Nation (Malawi); Malawi24; Capital Radio Malawi; Malawi Times; Face of Malawi
column17: On 9 October 2020, women, led by the Women's Manifesto Movement and the HRDC, took to the streets in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) in a demonstration against the President who, they say, promotes a system that oppresses women in the country, and to demand the fulfillment of the Gender Equality Act. [size=no report]

column7: Women (Malawi); Women's Manifesto Movement; HRDC: Human Rights Defenders Coalition
column16: Maravi Post; Malawi24; Face of Malawi; Malawi Times
column17: On 9 October 2020, women, led by the Women's Manifesto Movement and the HRDC, took to the streets in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) in a demonstration against the President who, they say, promotes a system that oppresses women in the country, and to demand the fulfillment of the Gender Equality Act. [size=no report]
Around 9 October 2020 (as reported), unemployed teachers took to the streets in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) to demand their employment by the government. [size=no report]

Around 13 October 2020 (as reported), chiefs of Mwanza gathered in Mwanza district to demand the immediate transfer of the Mwanza District Commissioner, the District Health Officer, and the District Environmental Health Officer. [size=no report]
On 17 October 2020, a women was stoned to death by a mob at Fumbwa village in TA Tambala (Dedza district, Central) after being accused of witchcraft. 2 people were arrested. [size=no report]

On 18 October 2020, Area 44 residents set several vehicles and part of the Kumbali Lodge on fire in Lilongwe (Lilongwe, Central) after community members were arrested for encroaching on the lodge's area. The group also looted proprieties; no one was injured. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2020, employees of Toyota Malawi gathered, with tree branches, in front of the company's offices in Blantyre (Blantyre, Southern) to demand a salary increment after an announcement that wages were not rising due to 'coronavirus challenges'. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2020, employees of Toyota Malawi gathered, with tree branches, in front of the company's offices in Mzuzu (Mzimba, Northern) to demand a salary increment after an announcement that wages were not rising due to 'coronavirus challenges'. [size=no report]

Around 20 October 2020 (as reported), a man was attacked and injured by a mob in Chilipa (Mangochi, Southern), after being accused of bewitching his wife. The group also damaged a police unit after police officers rescued the man. [size=no report]

Ivory nationals and supporters of the Ivory Coasts would-be president Alassane Ouattara, who lost an election due to internationally recognized fraud, begin a protest near the Ivory embassy in Bamako.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two civilians are injured when a bomb detonates in front of the French embassy. A suspect was taken into custody and found to be a Tunisian member of AQIM, whos aim was the destruction of the embassy.

Ivorian youths have staged a protest march, ahead of the sub-regional summit to be held on Sunday in Bamako, the Malian capital, calling for the departure of the outgoing Ivorian leader, Laurent Gbagbo.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A escaped fugitive and embassy bomber is captured by police while trying to flee into Algeria.
A schoolboy was killed when police broke up a demonstration by pupils at Koulikoro, a town in Mali 50 kilometers (30 miles) from the capital, a teacher and police said Tuesday.
A group of 100 unidentified armed men engaged the army in a remote region. No causalities or deaths reported.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: AQIM establishes a base of operations east of Nara, near the Mauritanian border.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanian troops arrest a person affiliated with AQIM in Mali territory.

A group of suspected Malian Tuaregs raided a settlement in Mali inhabited by Nigerien pastoral farmers last weekend (19 June), killing at least 12 and wounding a further 7. According to the Nigerien Interior Minister, Abdou Labo, who spoke on the regional Voix du Sahel radio, the perpetrators were of Malian origin and arrived on motorcycles carrying firearms before attacking the farmers.
Military forces launch patrols to root out pockets of AQIM, but have not reported engaging the enemy. This is a coordination with Mauritanian forces.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A number of bodies have been recovered after a Mauritanian army raid on an Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) camp in neighbouring Mali, a local official and other sources said Saturday. (15 dead)

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanian soldiers completely destroy"" a ""strongly fortified"" AQIM camp in neighboring Mali. Four troops wounded during the operation, fifteen AQIM members killed. Many bodies were discovered at the camp, buried and unburied.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A joint operation leads to 11 arrests of AQIM members, who where mainly Mauritanian.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Three civilians are killed by a land mine, most likely placed by AQLM, in Wagadou Forest. It is not clear if the civilians are Malian or Mauritanian.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two AQLM members are arrested by Malian forces in a remote region.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Military forces arrest fifteen members of AQIM during a raid.
A arms dealer is killed in the extreme north of the county while ferrying weapons to rebels in Libya. It is unclear as to the circumstance of his death.
Four are killed among drug dealers in the desert north.

column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanian aircraft attacking suspected al Qaeda insurgents in Mali at the weekend killed two civilians, a Malian defence source said on Monday, days after kidnappers crossed into Mali with seven foreigners abducted in Niger.

A Mali parliament member says seven people were hurt and tens of thousands of dollars of damage were done after a group of Muslims attacked a hotel and nightclub complex he owns in the capital of Bamako.
Armed men in cars stopped workers from starting to build a military barracks at Abeibara.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanian forces destroy a AQLM base in western Mali. AQLM chief reportedly killed.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanias army conducted an air raid to prevent a planned attack by al-Qaida-linked insurgents Thursday in a forest just across the border in Mali, where the group has a cell, the Mauritanian ministry of defense said.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A gang of armed men kidnapped two French nationals from their hotel in northeastern Mali overnight. The assailants are unknown initially, but are learned to be AQLM several days later.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Four Europeans are abducted by AQLM gunmen at a restaurant, one killed, one released in 2015 and the two others in June and July 2017. All other tourists were evacuated from the city after these events.
Hundreds gather to protest constitutional reforms believing these actions would take away many of their rights as citizens.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Special forces arrest several members of AQIM who they believe are responsible for kidnapping two Frenchmen in November.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A hotel manager and a guide have been arrested in Mali for involvement in the abduction of two Frenchmen in the northern town of Hombori last month. Authorities believe they are involved in AQIM.
Armed men from the Polisario Front -- a group seeking the independence of Western Sahara from Morocco -- killed a man and abducted three others in northern Mali.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: AQIM attacks a newly build military base, no report of causalities.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: AQIM publicly threatened five kidnapped Europeans with death if there were any efforts by the west or the Malian government to rescue them.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: MNLA rebels attacks two nearby towns and clash with government forces. Two soldiers killed and 47 MNLA fighters killed total among the two towns. Many others injured. Other unsubstantiated MNLA reports hold that government forces suffered much heavier losses. Civilians executed by AQIM, though the two organizations deny ties to one another.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: MNLA rebels attacks two nearby towns and clash with government forces. Two soldiers killed and 47 MNLA fighters killed total among the two towns. Many others injured.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: MNLA rebels carry out a killing of Malian soldiers at the Teacher training institute in Aquelhok. The assailants reportedly captured 153 soldiers and tied their arms behind their backs. 84 men (military estimate) had their throats slit or were executed with a bullet fired into the back of their head. Ansar Dine also claimed this attack as their own.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: MNLA rebels entered Aquelhok on 24 January 2012 and started firing at random.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: Rebels attack and take over a border town.
Groups gather to protest the government handling of MNLA attacks. Many of the protesters are family members of soldiers, claiming they are not properly equipped to handle attacks.
Protests of government handling of MNLA assaults in the north enters its second day.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: Government forces push back an advance by the MNLA.
Protesters upset over Tuareg attacks attack a Tuareg family living in the town and burn several business owned by Tuaregs.
Protests of government handling of MNLA assaults in the north enters its third day.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: Tuareg rebels took over the northern town of Menaka after the government forces stationed there pulled out overnight.

Rioters in Kati vandalized the pharmacy and clinic of a Tuareg doctor from Timbuktu & the house of the former Minister of Arts and Crafts and Tourism, who is of Tuareg origin. Police intervened to prevent mob lynchings.

Protestors surrounded the palace of Malis president, angry about the governments handling of attacks by Tuareg rebels in the countries north. The anger in Mali spills over into xenophobia as Touareg and other light-skinned populations have their homes and property vandalized.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: The Mali army said it had killed some 20 Tuareg rebels on Friday and Saturday in the northern city of Timbuktu and taken a dozen prisoners.

Hours after soldiers stormed state TV and radio in Mali, soldiers reported that young recruits had started rioting at a military base located outside the strategic northern town of Gao to demonstrate their discontent with the governments handling of the Tuareg rebellion. They demanded more weapons. The action is seen as a coup.

Soldiers displeased with the Tuareg rebellion in the north and how the Malian government is handling the situation fire their weapons into the air and storm the offices of a state broadcaster. The government sealed off the presidential palace in response, due to fears of a coup.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column17: Non-violent activity: Following recent gains in the north MNLA Tuareg rebels have proclaimed the ""independence of Azawad"", and declared Gao the capital. This declaration was immediately denounced by Ansar Dine, a rebel group that does not favor independence, but a united Mali that functions under Islamic law. The AU also rejects independence. This area encompasses the northern desert region of Mali.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: In the city of Gao, gunmen kidnapped seven Algerian diplomats, and gained control of the consulate building, according to witnesses and the Algerian foreign ministry. MUJAO claimed responsibility.
A group of young people stage a protest in Bamako against the occupation of the north.

Reports that in early April, an unidentified armed group ambushed a bus travelling on the outskirts of Gao and engaged in a battle with Ansar Dine members who arrived on scene to respond to the event. Ansar Dine members reportedly executed two of the armed bandits.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Movement of forces: More than 100 Boko Haram fighters have entered Gao following the Tuareg victory.

Agreement: Government forces release 22 kidnapped civilians after the taking of them prompted international criticism.
A Swiss hostage taken by Ansar Dine is released after negotiations from the government of Burkina Faso. She was later flown by helicopter to Ouagadougou.

column17: 3 civilians were wounded when their truck hit a mine.

column7: Military Forces of Chad (1990-); Military Forces of Mauritania (2009-); Military Forces of Mali (2013-2020); Military Forces of Niger (2011-)
column17: Two dozen ""militants"" were neutralized (killed/captured) in an operation involving forces from France, Mauritania, Niger, Mali and Chad as part of Operation Barkhane. Uncertain number of deaths coded as 10.
2 youths on a motorcycle opened fire on a bar, killing a young man and injuring 6 civilians, 4 seriously. The attackers are believed to have been Islamist militants.
2 youths were kidnapped from a convoy traveling from Algeria to Gao. They were taken by armed men near Anefis. Reports disagree about motives for the kidnapping.
2 Tuaregs who had disappeared earlier in November on the border with Algeria were found dead near Kidal bound in a mat and a blanket. It is not clear who killed them.
Detonation: A suicide bomber blew himself up in a market, causing no casualties or major property damage. No group claimed the attack.
In Aguelhok and Kidal, suspected al-Qaeda-linked rebels kidnapped 10 children and killed 2 others who tried to escape.
In Aguelhok and Kidal, suspected al-Qaeda-linked rebels kidnapped 10 children and killed 2 others who tried to escape.
Two soldiers killed and four or more wounded in a convoy providing security to a government minister when they drove over a landmine.

French forces have carried out 5 days of air operations, including airstrikes, over the Amettetai valleys in northern Mali. Four arms caches were destroyed and training camps were targeted. Casualties were not reported.

column7: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-); Military Forces of Chad (1990-)
column17: 38 to 100 Chadian MINUSMA soldiers abandoned their base in protest of late payments and demanding better working conditions. They returned after two days when MINUSMA agreed to improve camp conditions.

column6: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: 3 Chadian peacekeepers were injured, one seriously, when their vehicle hit a mine near Aguelhoc.

3 Malian civilians from the same family were kidnapped by armed men near Menaka. They are believed to have been taken by MUJAO, as other attacks have taken place in the same area carried out by MUJAO.

A joint operation by French and Malian armed forces killed at least 7 militant Islamists of the al-Murabitoun group, and at least 3 were taken prisoner. Among those killed was Ahmed el Tilemsi, the leader of the group.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: 3 Chadian peacekeepers were injured when their vehicle hit a mine near Aguelhoc. They were able to track down the bomb-layer and arrested 2 people found with heavy weapons.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column7: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad
column17: GATIA has claimed that a group made up of MNLA and MAA members raided Bamba. They allegedly stole property and kidnapped a resident of the town.

column6: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
column7: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad (Splinter Faction)
column17: GATIA and a splinter faction of the MAA have taken control of Bamba.

column6: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
column17: Looting: The MAA has claimed that GATIA raided the town of Ber near Timbuktu. They allegedly ransacked shops.

column6: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad
column17: The MAA has taken control of Taoudeni, an area that controls an important oil field.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: Ansar Dine has claimed a rocket attack on a joint-MINUSMA/Operation Barkhane (French) base. No casualties were reported.

column6: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
column7: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad (Splinter Faction)
column8: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column9: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad
column17: Between 1-6 people were killed when the MNLA and MAA clashed with GATIA and the MAA splinter faction supporting Bamako after GATIA opened fire on a vehicle. However, GATIA claimed 5 occupants of the vehicles had been killed before MNLA/MAA forces retreated. The 1 confirmed death was of an rebel MAA fighter.
A small boat traveling from Bamba to Timbuktu was attacked by rockets and automatic weapons fire but no casualties were reported. 2 passengers were reported missing however.

column6: CMA: Coordination of Movements of the Azawad
column8: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
column17: A CMA patrol clashed with GATIA fighters.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: Ansar Dine has attacked a joint UN/French/Malian military base, firing 4 rockets without causing casualties.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: 4 MUJAO fighters on motorcycles ambushed a car driving a Tuareg commander and mayor of Idheranbouker municipality, killing the driver and wounding the commander. He later died on his way to Bamako. His son was also killed in the attack.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: Property destruction: North of Gao, armed men burned 7 trucks contracted by MINUSMA to carry equipment, after ordering their drivers out. No casualties were reported.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: 8 UN peacekeepers from Niger were injured, 3 seriously, when their vehicle hit an explosive device on the road between Menaka and Ansongo.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: At least 3 Malian soldiers were killed in an attack by an AQIM militants on a Malian army camp in Nampala, after which the army retreated. The militants arrived in about a dozen vehicles.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Malian military forces regrouped with reinforcements and attacked AQIM militants who had pushed them out of the town earlier in the day. At least 8 soldiers were killed and 9 wounded according to military sources, while ""huge losses"" (coded as 10) were suffered by the AQIM militants.
An unidentified armed group shelled the city, targeting primarily military camps and the airport. No casualties were reported.
Suspected Islamist militants killed 1 person in an attack on Djoura, a village about 465 km northeast of Bamako.
9 deaths are recorded in Tenenkou between 8 and 16. FLM attacked soldiers, casualties unknown (4 recorded elsewhere).

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: 7 Senegalese UN peacekeepers were injured when their vehicle hit an explosive device while driving near Kidal airport.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: A gunmen on a motorcycle opened fire on a UN vehicle carrying peacekeepers from Niger killing 1. The man is allegedly part of the El Mourabitoune group.
Thousands of Malian Muslims marched to protest against the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad by Charlie Hebdo.
3 Malian soldiers and 1 civilian were killed when FLM attacked Tenenkou. 5 other military personnel were also injured during the attack and 6 assailants killed.
MINUSMA reported clashes between armed groups covered by the ceasefire in the area around Tabakort in the Gao region.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: ""militants"" attacked a MINUSMA camp in Kidal, killing 1 Chadian peacekeeper and injuring another. The attackers used a car bomb and artillery in their assault, but were repulsed. The attackers ""suffered losses"" (coded as 10).
Gunshots were heard and shells fired on Kidal. It is unknown who is responsible.

column6: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column8: CMA: Coordination of Movements of the Azawad
column17: In an exchange of fire with a car of Tuareg rebels, a MINUSMA helicopter shot missiles that killed four of the rebels.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: Tuareg protesters said they pushed UN personnel from an airfield, burning generators and tearing down tents. MINUSMA soldiers fired tear gas and warning shots but eventually fled.
Demonstraters in Gingal, a village near Mopti, marched in protest of French magazine Charlie Hebdos caricatures of the prophet Mohammed.
Malian troops were ambushed near Timbuktu. One gendarme was killed and one was injured; four of the attackers were killed.
Malian troops on their way to provide security for a weekly market in Douekire were ambushed by an unknown group. Two Malian soldier died and three were wounded.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: A huge crowd of youth stormed the MINUSMA headquarters in Gao, throwing stones and molotov cocktails. MINUSMA responded with tear gas and live ammunition, killing three and injuring four. A UN inquiry determined Rwandan policekeeping police used excessive force by opening fire on the crowd.

column6: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
column8: CMA: Coordination of Movements of the Azawad
column17: GATIA attacked a rebel Tuareg and anti-government Arab position near Tabankort, and at the same time 3 suicide bombings or rocket shells exploded, killing 12 total.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column7: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad
column17: Tuareg rebels clashed with progovernmental forces overnight near Kano. Rockets were fired, one person was killed, and 20 people were briefly taken captive.
An armed group attacked the village of Bamba, firing shots into the air and raiding shops. No deaths or injuries were reported.

column9: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: An armed group attacked the Kano village, kidnapping 20 -50 and killing one with a rocket. The villagers were all released shortly after thanks to pressure by MINUSMA.
French forces killed a dozen ""jihadists"" in a firefight in the extreme north, injuring several and taking two or three prisoner. They seized a large arms consignment and destroyed vehicles.
Military police repelled an attack by unidentified ""militants"" on their station in the western town of Dogofiry.
An army vehicle hit a mine near Timbuktu, death toll unknown.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: A ""militant action"" seriously wounded 6 Nigerien MINUSMA soldiers on the road between Asongo and Menaka.

column6: CMA: Coordination of Movements of the Azawad
column17: Pro-government armed groups took control of the town of Tabrichat in clashes with rebels.

column6: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad
column8: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group
column17: Rival armed groups from the MNLA and GATIA clashed in the Tessalit area. The MNLA accuses the Malian army of fighting alongside GATIA, but the government denies this. Casualties figures unknown.
Clashes occurred between Malian and Guinean miners between Feb.25-27. Clashes at the Sanfara site led to 3 (unspecified) dead and several Malians wounded.

Clashes occurred between Malian and Guinean miners between Feb.25-27, leaving a total of 6 dead. At least 3 people were found dead between Feb.26-27 in the Niawouleni territory of Mali, in the Sanfara area.

Clashes occurred between Malian and Guinean miners between Feb.25-27, leaving a total of 6 dead. At least 3 people were found dead between Feb.26-27 in the Niawouleni territory of Mali, in the Sanfara area.
Shortly after a peace accord was signed by leaders in Algiers, hundreds of demonstrators in Kidal rallied in opposition.
French soldiers clashed with a group of 8- 10 men, killing four and injuring several who fled.
Ater shooting several civilians at a nearby club, GMA shot and killed a police officer, a security guard, and a Belgian citizen on the street.
An angry mob lynched and burned the bodies of two Arab teenagers whom they believed had planted bombs in the area.

At least one gunman from the Al Mouribitoune jihadist group entered a club after midnight, threw grenades and opened fire, killing at least five people - including a French and a Belgian national - and wounding several.

column8: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
column17: A peacekeeper and two children were killed and several wounded when unknown militants shelled a UN base with more than 30 rockets and MINUSMA soldiers returned fire. Two civilians outside the camp died in the crossfire.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: 2 Malian civilians were kidnapped by jihadists as they tried to drive towards Niger.

column8: Military Forces of Mali (2013-2020) Special Forces
column17: Malian special forces raided the apartment of the suspects from the recent militant attack at a Bamako nightclub. At least one suspect fought back, explosions were heard, and the special forces killed at least one suspect, arrested about a dozen others, and three special forces sustained slight injuries.
2 soldiers killed and 6 injured by roadside bomb.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Al Qaida fighters shot a man in the head in front of villagers and then decapitated the victim. They accused him of working with French forces in Operation Barkhane.
Armed men stole a Malian government vehicle, prompting a guard to open fire as the men escaped.
Hundreds of supporters of exiled former president Amadou Toumani Toure called for his return in rallies held in Mopti and Gao.
Hundreds of supporters of exiled former president Amadou Toumani Toure called for his return in rallies held in Mopti and Gao.
Over one thousand supporters of exiled former president Amadou Toumani Toure rallied to call for his return.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Aid Workers (Mali)
